The decor is updated, but I think they could get better artwork on the walls cuz it's so cheesy as is.

 
There were only a few customers when we arrived, but we came during off hours so I'm sure this place can get busy.  The waitress was nice and told us to sit wherever we wanted. I was stupid and didn't double check yelp to see what to order, since it's been a long time since I bookmarked, so we got the seafood cocktail and regretted it because it was too bland. They needed to add some spice or something. Had I checked yelp I woulda known this cuz there are barley any pics of it and no one ever mentions it.....ugh. We also ordered the mussels and they were solid and a fairly large portion.

The best part of the entire meal was the bread! Holy crap, I could've eaten seconds and thirds of it but my stomach just couldn't stretch that far. I don't really like that you have to pay for it, but whatever. It was worth it and perfect for dipping in the broth.


I'd say the prices are a bit steep and nothing stood out, except the bread, so I won't be back any time soon. Oh and they didn't give us happy hour prices on the two beers even tho it was in fact happy hour, sooooooooo 
:-p.
author: Steph L.

description: Happy hour is awesome. Generally never let down. Good haunt for oysters and baseball. Not too crowed during the week.
author: Zac B.

description:
Ok you caught me! I'm here again!
Seriously been here 100 times?
From when Freddy welcomed me as the 4th customer to being the 1,000th doesn't matter, all his staff and probably his family treat it as so.......
So I will come here when ever in town( unfortunately living in a oyster lackluster town now) 
Jonathan always remembers me and my order guiding me on the best bubble to pair with my indulgent oyster order, which I never feel pressured to order the expensive ones.
author: robin n.

description:
We were pretty hungry on a Friday night, didn't feel like cooking, and had no dinner reservations. Our three criteria were: within walking distance of 21st & Valencia, no wait for two, and decent food. After a few stops, Mission Street Oyster was the first place we found that had open tables. 

THE WAIT: None at about 8:30pm on a Friday. We were seated immediately - the place had several open tables.

THE COST: about $70 for two entrees and a beer. This was quite pricey, and my boyfriend thought that Anchor Oyster Bar has a better selection on the menu for a comparable price, better quality food, and was just a nicer experience. 

THE ATMOSPHERE: It's like they couldn't decide between a sailboat, modern, and homey kitchen vibe. There's a half-hearted attempt at a seafaring theme up front with some boat paddles, lifesavers, etc. The bar has these sleek metallic lights that looked cool but didn't go with everything else. The bar itself is blue tile and the tables are simple wood, the kind you'd eat breakfast on at home. The walls are painted a bright blue, without much decoration on the walls. The whole place doesn't come together, it's kind of haphazard in an incomplete way.

Our server was very sweet & came by often. She read the specials off a notepad (and mentioned the prices, which was nice) and I went for the scallops - my boyfriend got the crab cake entree. They ended up being very, very similar dishes and I kind of wish she had mentioned something about that, especially since I was debating the Frutti di Mare that she had recommended. 

Dinner menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=Gf_jxnL10hls7veYIZ6uNg#rVEraX56aVAX0caXRmbmMg

APPETIZER
* Garlic Bread ($5.50) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=Gf_jxnL10hls7veYIZ6uNg#Gf_jxnL10hls7veYIZ6uNg
A really big serving - great melty cheese, strong garlic flavor, and crunch bread! This took a long time to come out - we got it after our entrees, and it should have come a little before. 

ENTREES
* Dungennes Crab Cakes (with potato wedges and vegetables, $21.95) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=Gf_jxnL10hls7veYIZ6uNg#JJ1BE8Q1nkqg1Jv0V8eXyQ
The veggies were just steamed, not much flavor. The wedges were spiced well, but the skin was a little dry. The crab cakes were moist and tasty, the dip fresh and tart. 

* Scallops (a dinner special) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=Gf_jxnL10hls7veYIZ6uNg#89FyBDsxTGaYYNr_doWTVA
Once again, simple steamed veggies. The scallops are baked & breaded, I liked the stringy texture that was preserved, and it had a garlic-y flavor. The mashed potatoes had some chunks to it and were slightly buttery and garlicy as well. Good but not overly impressive.

Overall, the seafood was good, but the dishes were pretty simple and not worth the price. I should have gotten the Frutti di Mare or Cioppino in retrospect! Would have given our dinner more variety and more interesting flavors.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Not THE BEST food in the mission but pretty darn good.
Clean. Great service. Pretty slow on a weekday & legit oysters. So stop on by & help them speed up their weekday business! They are worth a try.
author: Ashley G.

description: Came here on a Wednesday around 1PM and only one other table was occupied. This place has "happy hour" that starts pretty early in the afternoon, so you don't have to wait til 5:30PM or so and fight the crowd. Their happy hour price is $1.50 per oyster. Great price (just half the cost of Hog Island), and tastes great and fresh! I think because they have happy hour daily (or at least M-F), their oysters are fresh. (Note: Woodhouse Fish Grill, on the other hand, only does $1 oysters on Tuesdays, and I won't be going back for them; their Tuesday oysters don't taste fresh). I highly recommend this place!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
We took a chance bringing my dad here for his birthday because we hadn't been here. Hog Island is temporarily closed for renovation, and Anchor Oyster isn't open for lunch on Sundays. 

When we arrived I was skeptical--we were first patrons in the restaurant. To be fair - It was Noon on Superbowl Sunday. 

We ordered the Mission Special, the Cioppino, and the Garlic Crab. 

The Mission Special consist of 12 mixed oysters, steam prawns and clams. 
The oysters were very fresh, served with cocktail sauce and horseradish. The steamed clams and prawns were large and juicy. 

The Cioppino was filled with tender fish, crab and mixed shellfish. The sauce was delicious and rich. The Garlic Crab was just as sinful and delicious. EVERYTHING tasted really fresh!

The owners were extremely kind and friendly. I highly recommend this place to get your seafood fix!
author: Mimi T.

description: Loud as hell, but you can't beat the prices and happy hour deals. $1.50 oysters and $4 trumers, what's not to love? On top of that though, these guys have their service down. They have servers and waiters rotating in and around so quickly that you'll never be wanting for attention. Draft beer selection is just your standard one (Anchor, Lagunitas, Prohibition Ale, etc.), but it's only $6 for a pint, which is a steal for this day and age, particularly in the mission. The ambiance is decent enough with new chairs and tables, and the bar is clean. As for the food, I love the batter for the fish and chips. I don't enjoy the super briny taste to the fish, but it lets me know that the seafood is fresh. If you want bread and butter or garlic bread, it'll cost you ($6.50 for the latter). Service is strong, but quality of food could be better. I'll be back most likely for more seafood though. Be warned, it's not cheap here.
author: Danny C.

description: Just tried this place out with a friend and ordered the Miyagis oysters, scallops special, and clam chowder. The oysters lacked flavor/pop and went down tasting leftover and refrigerated for too long. The scallops were the best dish, but at $24 they certainly didn't impresss us. I haven't tasted a bad clam chowder in SF till now, way too watery. We were very polite to the waiter (who was helpful), but at the end of the meal when he asked how the food was, we told him we weren't super excited with the chowder...didn't complain about anything else. His only remark was "oh I'm sorry" and he walked away. There are way better seafood places to find in the city, don't waste your time here.
author: Ben J.

description:
This is my second visit all the way from Los Angeles. This place is legit! Let's cut to the chase- It's all about the Cioppino. It will rock your world. The broth is like crack; you can't stop slurping it up, dipping that amazing garlic bread in it and dredging up the copious amounts of seafood that shares the gigantic bowl with. Did I mention gigantic?  

   The other menu items we've tried were two different seafood pastas, fish and chips and of course oysters. Very happy with all choices so far

     Gotta mention the service. I didn't know until after our second visit last weekend that the server was the owner as well. I wish I knew his name, but whatever it is, he knows how to treat his customers well. He goes out of his way to make sure you are taken care of from start to finish. When we weren't sure which wines to order, her promptly brought out a few glasses and poured a few different tasters for us to try. That is quality service. 

    Go eat here! I promise you won't be disappointed.
author: Melissa H.

description: Great service and selections. Booked through Open Table but they report that they're not linked to Open Table anymore. Bummer.
author: L T.

description:
Went here around 630pm and when I walked in they asked if I had a reservation. I didnt know if we were suppose to make one, but they said it's alright and say us anyway! +1 star

As soon as we sat waiter asked us what we would like to drink. And when we were about ready to order she came around and asked if we heard about their special of the day. She was really friendly and service was great. Refilled water when it got low and never asked to have a refill on water. +1 star

I ordered the mission special which included fried prawns, calamari and oyster. The size was pretty decent and the quality was amazing. Also got the wine and roasted garlic pasta, very delicious and the clam chowder bowl was delicious! +2 stars!

Overall delicious place to eat but a bit pricey if you're looking for a bit more than regular price.
author: Jenny S.

description: Oysters were awesome and they had a huge selection.  Cioppino was the best i've had.  Service was A+.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Not very good. Bought the "premium" oysters for a $1 more than the ones on special. Big mistake.  They were the smallest Kumamotos I have ever seen. Service was terrible. Never came back to check in with us. Had to pay for bread and butter. Fucking lame. The busboy was great though. Now we are going to the boxing room for something good. 
Thanks for reading. 
Be excellent to each other, and party on dudes
author: Miles L.

description:
My friend brought me to this seafood spot in the mission one labor-free day because I wanted to explore the mission area of San Francisco and I suppose what better way than to grab fresh oysters on a sunny day as well!

I do love their raw oysters and I would recommend to just order that.  They offer 3 varieties on oysters.  When I was there, they were: Chesapeake, French Kiss and Miyagi.  My most favorite one was the Chesapeake!  It had a distinct, seawater flare that I liked about it very much.  The French Kiss and Miyagi does so as well, but it wasn't as strong as the Chesapeake.

It was $2 per oyster when we went there during non-happy hours.  Happy hours are everyday and even weekends, between 3pm-6pm.  When you get there for happy hour, it is a buck per oyster.  I would totally go on a weekend between those hours!  

They offer other seafood entrees as well, but nothing really captivated my attention besides the raw oysters.  On top of that, their seafood plates are on the pricey side.  You're talking about catering to the mission area as well.  

Other than the raw oysters here, I am passing through Mission!
author: Tiffany D.

description: The oyster were delicious. But the chowder was nothing special, even though other reviews rave about it. Very casual and the music was strange and didn't fit the vibe at all. I would still come back for the oysters though as they were fresh.
author: Isabelle P.

description: My wife wanted oysters for mothers day . Found this place on yelp . Didn't know what to think of the place but the tile floor was a put off and no lining,  only paper napkins .. still the food and service was great...
author: Samir Z.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Monday real quick for their happy hour oysters. We had been wandering around the city and were going to go home but determined to find some hh oysters. We were the only table here (except for someone at the bar whom I am not sure if they even ordered anything).

We sat ourselves and ordered quickly. Since we were the only people, our oysters (a dozen each) also came out quickly. I got a variety because I wanted to taste most of theirs and they weren't bad, pretty fresh. The service was good considering we were here for like 15 minutes.

Quick visit, quick service, quick review.
author: Kat C.

description:
Went for the weekend all day happy hour - $2/oyster. There were five oysters choice, tried one each before deciding to go for 2nd round of oysters with our preferred choices. 

Glad that the oysters were of decent size and fleshy. Had bad experiences at other oysters bar where they offered tiny oysters for happy hour! So this was good.

Ordered their French fries to accompany our oysters. They were yummy, though a rather small portion.


The decor is simple and non-pretentious. It's quite easy to miss them too if you weren't specifically looking out for it.

Service was friendly and good. Overall, we had a good experience. Will be back when the oyster craving hits.
author: Cindee T.

description: I love the crab salad at Mission Street Oyster Bar, that's why I keep coming back. Gotta feed the cravings!
author: Yvette K.

description: I was here for the happy hour oysters. It was $1.50 per oyster, and there were five different types of oyster to choose from. They were all very fresh and tasty. I will be back again!
author: Connie H.

description: Delicious see food and probably the best Cioppino in town. Surprisingly it is easy to get a table, even on weekends.
author: Klemens W.

description:
Recently came to this place with friends. We were surprised to find the food are very delicious and well made. There are many options of Oysters, though lack of baked options like Hogs Island. 

We ordered two pastas, two steamed mussels for entry, all four courses are very flavorful and in big portion. I would compare the quality of food with Chez Maman even though it's not really a French restaurant. 

The services were very nice and prompt, the bread was warm and fresh. 

Compare to all the restaurants on Valencia street, this one had no line and was quiet on a Tuesday evening at 8pm. The location might have contributed to it. 

Overall, I highly recommend it!!
author: Mary L.

description:
I've been coming here for about 2 years, once-twice a month. Staffing changed recently and quality PLUMMETED!

Yes, oysters live in the sea, and a salty brine is part of the experience. Sadly, on my last visit, the oysters were literally drowned in table salted water. HORRIBLE! 

Basic stuff like friendly KNOWLEDGEABLE staff, clean bathrooms and properly handled oysters seem to be a thing of the past. This place sure took a dive! Too bad!

And what's with offering only ROSE for the specials, anyway? That stuff was undrinkable!
author: A F.

description:
I was craving oysters big time so I turned to yelp for some guidance and that's how I found this place. What drew me in was their happy hour for oysters. It's $1.5/oyster from noon-6pm Monday to Friday and $2 a piece on the weekend. I ordered 2 dozens to start, 4 different kinds of oysters. One of them was the kusshis which actually cost a little more ($2.75 each). They were all good but kusshis were the best (of course everything I like is usually pricey).

I also got a bowl of New England clam chowder and a plate of black mussels. They brought me garlic bread on the house. Needless to say, I was super satisfied and probably spent a little too much but it's worth it. I would come back when I am in town. I do recommend this place for all seafood lovers. :)
author: Hannah T.

description:
I had a good experience here last night!  The food was excellent.  The service was decent, and the biggest drawback was that there was a funny smell when I entered, but it seemed to go away.

My friend and I shared the cioppino (the broth is amazing, and the dish is full of different types of seafood).  It was delicious.  We also enjoyed a half dozen oysters - my favorite was the Kumamoto.'

The service was ok.  Our waitress was friendly and the food came out quickly.  However, she was not good at checking on us during the meal.  We had to flag her down to ask for more bread and water glass refills.  

The worst part was the strange smell I encountered when I walked in - it seemed to dissipate over time (or maybe I just got used to it).

The atmosphere is pretty blah - not a very inviting or attractive decor.

Overall, it was the high quality of the food that earned this spot four stars in my book!
author: Barnali D.

description:
We loved our Valentines dinner at the bar!  Jonathan great waiter - you rock!

We had eighteen oysters since the Fanny Bay were so good... than the lobster special and we started with the clam chowder soup which was amazingly delicious as well!

Love this hidden gem and can't wait to return on our next trip to SF.
author: Clara B.

description:
We enjoyed the food but wow the service was so off, we had to knock it down and won't go back.  It also doesn't help their prices are super high $$$$

First, the major issue.  We came here for the $2 happy hour oysters on Sunday and ordered a dozen oysters.  They charged us $3 per oyster for half of them. We asked why, when we got the bill.  Because some were "premium".  How would we know that, we ask?  Because it's on the board over there?  Over where, we ask?  On that board behind the cash register.   Oh, the board we can't see from our table?!  A good waiter would have been upfront about this.

The bowl of clam chowder came out cold, and we had to ask them to take it back and heat it up.   I Have never had to do this before (you can see from my 500+ reviews we eat out a lot)

Then, they totally forgot us when we tried to pay the bill and , after waiting over 25 minutes, we finally had to get up and go track someone down to be able to pay. 

We are the types that NEVER ask for any special attention, we are low maintenance, and It so disappointing, and ruined an otherwise nice evening.

We walked here from the Marsh on Valencia, where we saw Eating Pasta Off The Floor, which was sooooo good!  Loved it.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
2.5 STARS

It surprises me how many people hate hipsters. A quick Google search and I found hundreds of websites and blogs with people professing their hatred for them. Geez, harsh much? Admittedly, I'm not a fan of hipsters yet I regularly find myself in "the" hipster mecca of San Francisco: The Mission. 

I'm such a hypocrite. So does that make me a hipster too? 

If only I could shoe horn my way into skinny jeans without looking like I have a camel toe. Anyhow...

Hipster mecca aside, The Mission is the breeding ground for the newest and hottest restaurants in San Francisco. Instead of going to Hog Island at the Ferry Building, my friends and I decided to check out the new oyster bar in The Mission for happy hour. 

We were disappointed. My friends suggested 2 stars but I'll be nice and round up. 

I absolutely adore Anchor Oyster Bar (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco#hrid:p84AaAmuoJL-9jFCU8Esfg) and after reading that Mission Street Oyster Bar's owner worked there for 18+ years, I expected the same caliber in terms of food quality especially with their Fisherman Wharf prices. Not only was the food lackluster, the service was unorganized and snail paced, and the tacky teal ambiance left little to be desired.   

It seems the owner bought a taqueria and just added two flat screen TVs. Viola! A hipster "oyster bar" is born. Mission Oyster Bar is not an "oyster bar" per say as there's no seafood display and all the shucking is done in the kitchen in the back. It's very bare boned and all the empty space makes it uninviting. 

The Happy Hour menu (everyday 3 pm - 6 pm) consists of $1 oysters (3 varieties), $2.50 draft beers, and one house wine for $7.  

Four solid stars for the fresh oysters and offering three varieties: Fannie Mae, Chesapeake Bay and Miyagi (my fav) http://bit.ly/XiwjZk. DO COME FOR THE OYSTERS! They were super silky and sweet but a mignonette would have been better than the accompanying cocktail sauce. Kudos to Mission Oyster Bar's awesome oyster supplier. Unfortunately, all the praising stops there. 

We decided to order a small sampling of the menu in the event we wanted to come back for dinner. The Clam Chowder ($5.50) tasted generic http://bit.ly/Y3999u. It was watery, bland, and there was barely any clams in it. Not only did it take 45 minutes to arrive, it arrived lukewarm. The much raved about Garlic Bread ($4.95) wasn't garlicky and was over toasted to a hard crouton http://bit.ly/YzSDwQ. The mediocre Dungeness Crab Cakes ($11.95) were made with minced crab meat not lump crab and similar to what I've bought at Trader Joe's http://bit.ly/15iWUZB. 

And then there's the service. The restaurant is understaffed and the staff lacks training. One waitress for 10 tables and the bar is not enough. We were never given basic things like plates, forks or spoons nor were any of the oysters described; they were just plopped onto our table. Our additional rounds of oysters were wrong (we wanted miyagis only) and came without lemon and oyster forks. Again, there was the 45 minute wait for lukewarm clam chowder which is inexcusable after two reminders to our waitress and one of the chefs.

After being opened for 2 months, I would have expected for Mission Street Oyster Bar to have ironed out major kinks. Seems like they haven't. 

I will leave Mission Street Oyster Bar for the hipsters to have at it....
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Happy Hour Details:
Mon-Thurs | (3-6pm)
$6 Wine (rotating) and $4 Beer (that is regular price)
$1.50 Oysters (limitations)

They offer several oysters for $1.50 (new price change), and the quality is far superior to Hog and Rocks which is just around the corner and offers a similar deal on a single oyster type. Hog and Rocks had so many shards of oyster shell, it was impossible to eat. The oysters here were better shucked, and also really great quality - Fannie Mae was my favorite.

I'm a little wary to order anything other than the oysters after reading several reviews. I would definitely recommend this place for oysters and beers during happy hour though!
author: Jess C.

description:
$1 Oysters and $2.50 beers at the new seafood resto few doors down from Mission Chinese!  Next time I gotta try and make it before 6pm! 

Stumbled in for dinner as a group of 10, the new paint and overall newness made it stand out in this part of the Mission. Out waitress was great. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=Po7vvqgV9KBOVNFwpO2tUA#Po7vvqgV9KBOVNFwpO2tUA)

I liked how they cooked all the seafood to order without overcooking anything.      

Here's some of the dishes we shared family style. 

*Steamed shell fish combo | $21 
Clams with both black and green mussels in this roasted garlic white wine type broth. They have a special right now in how they're giving FREE garlic french bread. Went so good with that broth! Probably this along with the frutti were the best dishes of the night. The broth was good BUT I've had more addictive ones from some of the nearby Tapas restos. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=7OR8rillLZl5Wp43S6ma7w#7OR8rillLZl5Wp43S6ma7w)

*Frutti di Mare | $29
Basically everything in the steamed shellfish combo along with chunks of fish and prawns. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=kM5z9o9K1B899inbT9nQDQ#kM5z9o9K1B899inbT9nQDQ)

*Fried Mission Special | $17
Breaded and fried oysters, calamari, and prawns. Nice crunch but nothing special.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=m3g4o5zBeJS21C9ZmPjEXQ#m3g4o5zBeJS21C9ZmPjEXQ)

*Calamari | $13 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-street-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=TWjC2M8vizZD9Gd_3bQ4Mg#TWjC2M8vizZD9Gd_3bQ4Mg)

*Fish and chips | $16 

*Spicy garlic prawns | $20 
Nice flavor but not worth the $$$ given the amount of shrimp. 

*Daily pasta with your choice of sauce (marinara, alfredo, etc) 

*Their clam chowder was more potatoes than clams and surprisingly the only dish on a table full of guys that went unfinished. Something was off. 

Solid flavors but it's not anything fancy with developed flavors. Prices are fair, but for this part of the Mission, was looking a little more bang. For this price point, I like Woodhouse Fish a little bit better.
author: Earl G.

description:
Not all oysters produce pearls. But just because an oyster lacks a pearl doesn't mean they aren't valuable to me.  In fact I  looked forward this past Friday to try this new oyster Bar located on a couple doors down from Taqueria Cancun.  

We arrived around 5pm, still an hour before Happy Hour ends so we ordered  14 ($1) oysters to start and 2 ($2.50) Stella beers.  They have all the usual types, Blue Points, Kumamotos, etc.  My favorite being Kumamotos.  They are small but have a nice fresh and sweet taste.  

After our oysters we ordered:

Combination Seafood Salad $22.95: a combination of prawns, Shrimp, and Dungeness Crab. A generous amount of seafood over mixed greens and tomatoes.  Your choice of dressing. 

Cioppino $28.95:  Delicious tomato based broth served with a nice amount of fish, prawns, shrimp, clams, mussels, and crab.  Maybe because it was colder than Bashar al-Assad's heart outside that night but the cioppino really hit the spot.  In fact I liked it so much I wanted to talk to the chef and it turns out he was a chef at Anchor Oyster bar for 18yrs.  It really shows in the food that Chef Freddie is a pro.

Our waitress Maria was friendly and attentive.  The restaurant looks brand new as well as the restrooms.  The kitchen is in plain view so you can watch the chef and cooks preparing the food.  A couple flat screens at the bar to watch the games on.

To me this restaurant is a pearl in the Mission that happens to serve oysters..
author: Michael L.

description: Everything about this place was so good! I shared the Mission platter with two other girlfriends and two house salads with the garlic dressing. Knocking off 1 star for no happy hour on New year's day. The oysters tasted fresh, the salad was also fresh with that amazing dressing, and oh man, the garlic bread was delicious on it's own, but dip it in the broth with steamed clams and prawns, heaven. The clams were OK, but the prawns were big and juicy. Satisfied and I hope to be back.
author: Nani V.

description:
WHOA.
Visited with my brother. It's not fancy at all. Great selection of oysters, and we also shared cioppino. Yum. The bread it comes with is amazing, the broth fantastic, and a good assortment of seafood. Our oyster starter (we ordered a mix of the premium) was easily one of the best we have had.
Don't expect something fancy. The joint is on Mission in the middle of some not so delightful retail spots. And their focus is on the food and the service, not on decor. It's clean. And the food excellent. What else matters on a Sunday night having dinner with my bro?
author: Amy O.

description: I loved this place. We originally stopped in for a beer but when we saw the menu, we changed gears and made it dinner. The oysters were fresh and the selection was great. We also had a whole crab that was hot, buttery and garlicky to perfection. The service was friendly and flawless. We had a slight issue with some wine by the glass that wasn't good and it was cheerfully replaced. MSOB is now on my list of approved oyster joints.
author: Brian B.

description:
Stopped in for Happy Hour Oysters on Tuesday around 4:00PM.

Beer & Wine only, the selections are pretty good.

We really enjoyed the layout and decor of the place. The walls are refreshingly soft against the dark colours of the tables/ bar.

Maria, who was working behind the bar was delightful right from the start. Charming, kind, attentive and just chatty enough to be pleasant. She was also really knowledgeable about the different types of Oysters, which was impressive. Even went out of her way to see if the Kitchen would make something for us that wasn't on their regular menu.

The Oysters were Fresh and are $1 during Happy Hours. They are served with Horseradish cocktail sauce and lemons.

We also requested the Avocado Salad, which is not on their menu but was a special the night my boyfriend, J walked by, it caught his eye and decided him and I would need to stop in. They were so kind in putting this together for us and the crab meat was YUMMY!

I would absolutely return here and look forward to trying their other dishes.
author: Meghan L.

description: One of my favorite stops when I come into the city. Oysters are always fresh and the crab Burger today was outstanding. Service is always speedy and friendly. Great selection of wine and beer.
author: Rudy N.

description: Came here just for oysters on Saturday. Got the $2 happy hour ones, the miyagi oysters were the best! Didn't try any of the other food, but I'd come again.
author: Sean W.

description:
Most fantastic seafood we've had in a long time! Date night was way more fun with great food.

The Mission Street special had everything lightly breaded and perfect in a million ways. 5-star appetizer.

Husband had Shellfish combination and I had Pasta with prawns in light tomato cream sauce. Sheer awesomeness!!! Clean atmosphere and Mel was super friendly. She recited the day's special with such enthusiasm ,warmth and good memorization... she was legit! 

Definitely coming back with friends:)
author: Stefanie C.

description: I wanted to really like this place. The calamari had NO type of flavor to it. It was so bland and so were the deep fried oysters. Like not even a hit of salt or anything. Didn't even want to order any of the entrees after that, very disappointed. Had a Rockefeller Oyster for the first time which was pretty good tho.
author: Justine L.

description: Stopped here while visiting San Fran, everything was great! The oysters were fresh and the pasta was to die for! Our waitress was very attentive, will definitely come again while visiting San Fran.
author: Aisha S.

description:
Went to this place for the first time last night. AMAZING!
Food was perfect, great taste , reasonable prices.Had artichoke, 6 oysters, fried special calamari, 2 orders of garlic shrimp and 2 glasses of wine ( I know we were hungry!!) our bill was $112. Super happy! Btw it was after HH time
author: Rana K.

description: Great service, fun vibe. In addition to the fabulous seafood options, order the garlic bread and side salad with creamy Italian dressing. Good value for oysters compared to a few other places in the city.
author: Vicki L.

description: One word is more than enough to describe this place: DELICIOUS! Do you love shrimp? If the answer is yes then this is the place to go! I do love seafood and I think that Mission Street Oyster Bar is the perfect place for me to satisfy my seafood cravings -- sometimes I even come here when I want to enjoy pasta along with the nice weather. My ultimate favorites: fish and chips, scallops, shrimp cocktail, oysters and clam chowder (soo thick, creamy and yummy). Oh and I can't forget to mention the cioppino... spicy and flavorful! I've dragged all my family here several times and they have loved it.
author: Donald S.

description:
Had a craving for oysters and was not disappointed here. Tried their Fanny Bay and French Kiss selection, although we missed their happy hour. Their clam chowder and garlic bread were great as well.

Service is great, but parking sucked even though we were there on a Wednesday night after 7:30p, but it's the Mission, so eh what can ya do?
author: April S.

description:
Ok....I have made two visits here....and need to head back.

1.  Location is on Mission St, and walking distance from the 16th St Bart station, and around the corner from the bar scene on Valencia.

2.  The venue is cool and airy.....and I love this.

3.  The food is absolutely amazing.....raw oysters, the garlic bread....but the crab and shrimp salad buckled my knees.....so good.  Nothing could top this......but then my daughter ordered the cioppino, and it was over the top amazing.

4. Service was solid every visit....(my wine glass never went empty).

I love this place!!!
author: Tom P.

description: The food was good, very small portions though for the price. We also really didn't like that they charge extra for bread when you order any of the cooked shell fish, kind of of to do this. The service was good as well.
author: Danielle R.

description:
First time visiting San Fran and couldn't wait to try some good seafood. The night before we went to an upscale seafood spot and it wasn't nearly as good as Mission Street Oyster Bar. The food here was awesome and definitely worth 5 stars. I'm a bit skeptical about fish but I loved everything we ordered. I strongly suggest the crab cakes, shrimp cocktail and the caesar salad (which has actual toasted garlic bread as croutons, how great?). The Rockefeller oysters were good too just a little too salty for my taste.

I would have given this place stars but the service was super slow and pretty forgetful. We waited about 15 minutes at the bar before getting drinks. Granted, it was a busy Saturday night but from other reviews it seems like this is a bit of a trend here. 

Overall, a great restaurant and would love to come back on our next trip to SF!
author: Skye F.

description:
I was excited to try this place as it is both more convenient and cheaper than schlepping all the way to Hog Island in the Ferry Building when I'm looking for some bivalves.

I think three stars pretty much sums it up.  It wasn't bad, by any means, but it wasn't great either.  The oysters may have been inexpertly shucked, there was basically no brine left in many of them, which caused the flavor to suffer.  The oyster shooters were a bit mystifying, there was at least 6 oz. of liquid, *way* too much to "shoot" so I had to sip on mine for a while before I could knock back the oysters at the bottom.  Not bad at all, but a little confusing.

The ambiance also left something to be desired.  There are a couple of big marlins mounted on the walls, but other than that there really wasn't much going on in the decor department.  Nautical decor can be tough to pull off, but it's worth it to try.  See GT Fish and Oyster in Chicago for an example of major nautical theme while remaining elegant.

The prices and the location mean that I'll likely be back, but it doesn't quite serve as an equal to Hog Island.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Great food. Service was attentive. Good place for kids as well, very accommodating. 

Must get the cioppino! YUMO! Ask for kids plated pasta (not on menu, but if you ask nicely they will make them for the kiddos.)
author: Curious A.

description: Fabulous Happy Hour and oyster selections. Both of the waitstaff on hand was top notch. They throughly explained the selections and were so attentive to us. They accommodated our 4 year old and made her feel special as well. They thing to note though is that this definitely is in a bit of a sketchy neighborhood. We weren't quite prepared for that. But the oysters and the amazing service made up for it!!
author: Brooklyn R.

description: $2 or $3 oysters for lunch on Sunday! We tried 6 different varieties that I can't recall the names of, but I loved them all. They were all really fresh and served on a nice platter of ice with cocktail sauce, horseradish and a vinaigrette sauce. This restaurant is right in the Mission district, and one of the places we just had to stop in while exploring the area. I'd definitely return.
author: Monica V.

description: Go here and order it. All of it. It's all good. And happy hour is killer. And why does Yelp make you write a novel just to give someone a proper review? What else do you want me say? Hopefully they figure that out soon or I'm just gonna write "dicks" over and over and over again.
author: James H.

description: Anchor Oyster Bar on Castro is better than this place for a few reasons. First I agree with the other Yelpers about the nickel-&-diming. My friend wanted a piece of bread-- no go. It's ciabatta bread not sour dough & they charge you $2.50. Ridiculous. But--This place is really good. Incredible oysters $2 each-- miyagi, fanny bay, Kumamoto-- all great, nice mignonette , really tasty. Fresh, delicious seafood except for the shrimp, which did taste frozen, but the sole was good. I like more seasoning, but they have tapatio on the table so it was cool. The Phil Collins background music was annoying & made us miss Anchor, where some of these cooks used to work. It's cool that they're here, the space is larger than anchor. That being said, the music sucked, the bread's over-priced just like the other Yelpers wrote. If this place fixes that & the over-cooked frozen shrimp, it'll be perfect.
author: Scott F.

description: Succulent oysters paired with well-selected wines and beer.  Add a hip, clean decor and knowledgeable servers and you have a recipe for success.  Get here before 6 for $1.50 oysters.  Fantastic dinner lineup....didn't sample as had reservations elsewhere, and this was a pre-dinner stop.  As someone who lives for good oysters on the Chesapeake Bay, this is the real deal!
author: Tom K.

description:
A bit pricey for the menu items (crab burger, prawn appetizer, crab appetizer) but good quality and pleasant service.

$1.50 oysters Monday to Friday, 12 to 6 p.m., a good deal.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Cioppino here is amazing, and HUGE. My husband and I split that and an order of garlic bread, plus an appetizer (happy hour oysters + crab stuffed avocado), and we're all set. 

This is a pretty chill, no frills seafood place. Food is excellent and portions are big, service is great, and the space is large. Would be great to have a group of friends here. Food can be pricey but it's fresh seafood, so you're paying for the best stuff.
author: Sahar B.

description: So happy to found this place around my neighborhood. Fresh oysters, helpful waitress. We came when they just opened for the day and it was quiet. But when we left the place is full of people.. would be coming back for sure
author: I P.

description: We went to this place last week. Figured it was a good option in the Mission. It was around 4pm in the afternoon on a Wednesday. There was a total of 2 people at a table already eating. We sat at the Bar and started to look at the happy hour menu. There was a total of one option for beer, and one option for wine. Only one option for oysters. This is not a surprise for the Happy Hour Menu. I asked for a sample of the beer and was given one. It was acceptable. My friend asked for a sample of the Rosé. The person behind the bar said they don't give out small samples of it. So we just ordered a glass. It tasted bad, flat and weird. We asked her if we could see the bottle. She very hesitantly showed it to us. It was just about to the end. So it must of been sitting there for some time. Looked like an $7 dollar bottle. She was very indifferent, not welcoming at all. It just seems she really did not want to be there. We looked at each other and decided to gulp my beer and leave. We were amazed on how an establishment like that in San Francisco - could stay in business. It was so disappointing overall.
author: Jayme L.

description:
An oyster bar that doesn't know how to properly shuck oysters... *sigh*

Sandy and I were craving oysters after brunch this past Sunday. We wanted to hit up Anchor Oyster Bar but it was closed so we settled on MSOB since it was the only option within walking distance. 

The place is really chill - high ceilings and mellow ambiance. When we walked in, we were excited to try their oysters.

We ordered two of each - Kumomotos, Miyagi and Kusshi oysters. All six half-shells came on a typical platter filled with ice, two lemon wedges, cocktail sauce, horseradish and vinegar. It looked great at first glance. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A Everything was going well until we took down our first oysters, the Kumomotos. Man, they were so gritty and I knew immediately it's because they didn't shuck them correctly. Sandy said the same thing so I started becoming weary of the other ones. Well, the Miyagis and Kusshis were the same story. *sigh again*

We also ordered a shrimp cocktail... wait, it was a prawn cocktail. That was actually pretty good. The prawns were nice and plump. 

We came for the oysters. We left in disappointment.
author: Bruce C.

description:
Wow. What a great find!

I went into the Mission to check out an art gallery and ended up really hungry after. We wanted a drink, but also did not want pub food. We looked across the street and saw this place. I saw that the reviews were good, so we decided to try it. 

On Saturday and Sundays, they have a $2 oyster special. I ended up not having oysters because all of their cooked food looked delicious.

There were four of us and we shared the Mission Special (fried calamari, fried shrimp and fried oysters) and it was so good! The seasoning they used on the food was really yummy. My boyfriend got the crab burger (thick crabmeat on a bun with avo and the works) and clam chowder. My brother's girlfriend got shrimp Alfredo with penne and garlic bread. I got the crab cake appetizer. They gave you a generous amount of seafood and it was super fresh. Our bill was $103. Not bad! 

I will definitely be back to try the oysters.
author: Melissa S.

description:
UPDATE:  $1 oyster happy hour is Mon-Thur only.  Not everyday as we thought.

We arrived for happy hour on Fri to find the oysters are $2 - not a great deal.  For now, all day Fri-Sun oysters are $2.  It was empty when we arrived.  There were only 3 other people in the place during our stop.

We tried:
Rock point
Kusshi
Kumai
Kumamoto - always a fav
Fanny Bay
Somerset 

Added Kusshi & Kumai to our list of favs.  The oyster crackers provided on the bar were good because they cleared our palate between oysters.

We sat at the bar & service was fine.  Entrée prices seemed overpriced & we weren't compelled to order any.
author: Kim S.

description:
Came here on a Thursday around 6pm and there was only a big group seated right in front of the door. I must say, this restaurant is located in a pretty ghetto run down area. My bf and I got off the 16th St Bart exit and while walking there, we witnessed multiple arguments in the middle of the sidewalk and the same happened as we were walking back to Bart. 

We ordered clam chowder, mission fried special, and the mission special. When we asked our waitress which oysters were the fattest, she just listed all of the available oysters which wasn't very helpful. Everything was pretty tasty, however, all of the oysters had some bits of the shell mixed in it which kinda ruined the experience. I would definitely recommend the steam clams though cause they were finger licking tasty good!

Overall, I much rather go to Hogs Island for my oyster fix.
author: Renee Y.

description:
WOW! If you are a seafood fan and you've already had the Hog Island and Swan Oyster experience I would recommend you give this place a go.

They have a great selection of freshly shucked oysters. 
When we went there were at least 10 to choose from. 
Our waitress was VERY knowledgeable and helpful with recommendations when it came to choosing oysters... Which was much needed considering the variety they had on the night.

TO START - Mixed Dozen of Oysters and the Combination Cocktail. 
What a start!!
All oysters were very fresh and shucked well. Really enjoyed the French Kiss Oysters from New Brunswick Canada and ordered half a dozen more (could of easily ordered more and more). 
That's probably why they have the records on the wall of people eating dozens and dozens of oysters... The record right now is set at 300 odd - The feeling must be mutual in regards to these tasty bad boys. 

Combination cocktail was a great but wish it came with 2 prawns instead of the one as we were sharing our dishes. But it was a "starter" and it came with a decent portion of crab and shrimp which was enough to share. 

MAIN - Cioppino with chilli flakes and a side of garlic bread. 
There is no shortage of seafood in this dish! 
The combination of fresh seafood and different flavours make it just amazing. 
This is up there with one of the BEST seafood dishes that I've had.
***It was definitely a stand out dish from our visit to SF***
author: Glen C.

description:
I was actually in town for a basketball tournament, and we found Mission Street Oyster Bar on Yelp and just had to give it a try. We had a party of 13 people, and they sat us fairly quickly given that we just walked in with no reservations.

There was only 1 server the entire night and a few busboys refilling your water. The lone server was AMAZING though. Even though you could see the stress on her face, she was helpful with recommendations, always checking up on us, and just accommodating us as much as she could.

Local Petrole Sole ($23.95)
Stuffed with crabcake and baby shrimp, the Petrole Sole was a little small in quantity but great on taste. It comes garnished with mashed potatoes and veggies. You may not see it on the menu because it was one of the specials.

Cioppino ($29.95)
I saw this dish posted ALL over Yelp, so we had to order it. There is SO much seafood! A little pricey but so worth is (especially if you're a huge seafood fan like myself).

Garlic Crab ($32.96)
I have NEVER been to a place that gives you THIS much crab. There is a TON of crab. You can get full of just this dish alone eating only the crab legs. Huge portion with HUGE flavors. Awesome.

Clam Chowder (Bowl) ($5.50)
Highly recommended. Nice and creamy, but the best part is that it's CHUNKY. Lots of clams and potatoes (just the way I like it).

Garlic Bread ($5.50)
THIS IS A MUST! They use ACTUAL garlic on top of the bread. It's amazing. It's a huge hit on Yelp, and now I can see why.

Overall, I'm in love with this place (especially the Garlic Bread, Clam Chowder, and Garlic Crab). My one knock is that we waited an hour (literally) for our food once we ordered. Given it was a busy Saturday evening, an hour is still a little too long no matter where anyone goes. Nonetheless, the seafood was fresh and it was our best meal in SF when we were up there.
author: Calvin L.

description:
Sweet place to get some half-price oysters on a weekday. Their oysters are good than their other dishes are alright. The crab-filled avocado appetizer is underwhelming, but I've enjoyed the food overall.

My advice? Get a Mission Special or oyster platter and a bottle of wine with friends for a light meal. The servers are pretty friendly as well.
author: Irina P.

description:
The fiancé and I were in the city and were craving some oysters.  We did a little yelping around and decided to give Mission Street Oyster Bar a try and we were both happy with our experience.

THE ORDER

Oysters - 4 out of 5 - They oysters were the highlight of the meal and we ended up doing 3 orders.  We really enjoyed the Sumer Sets, Rock Points, Kumomotos and Church Points best of all.

Fried Calamari - 4 out of 5 - Really well done.  The calamari were really well prepared.  They had a nice batter which wasn't over powering and didn't fall off the calamari.  It comes with two dipping sauces.  The tarter sauce was just ok with the cocktail sauce being really good.

Garlic Bread - 3.5 out of 5 - Really good garlic bread, almost great.  The bread comes pretty thickly sliced covered with cheese, garlic, some basil and a little tomato sauce.  I really wish there was a little more garlic flavor to the bread, other than that the bread was soft with a nice crust and pleasantly cheesy. 

OVERALL

Great experience and nice little place to hang out, especially for happy hour, if you are in the area.
author: Rob P.

description: Had excellent oysters, a variety, on the half shell, then just-right broiled scallops with a tasty green salad (in place of the mashed potatoes offered on the menu), then shared a delicious ciopinno. Good service all the way through.
author: William G.

description:
Always a good idea.
There are a few kinds of oysters any day of the week, 5 or more. And these are only for happy hour, they have even more kinds besides that. 
My boyfriend and I ate 6 dozens and didn't die! Lol
author: Julia O.

description:
Best seafood meal ever! Great service. 

Ordered the daily pasta with prawns, spicy prawn scampi and fresh oysters during happy hour. Everything was amazing!
author: Cherri Y.

description:
I made a reservation through opentable yesterday since i have the opentable pay first-time user deal (promo code: pumpkin), so I have choose the Mission Street Oyster Bar and Seafood restaurant. When I first arrived the restaurant, I asked about the opentable pay detail. The person who served me told me that they didn't accept opentable pay and/or the promo since they didn't have any computer or wifi at all. But I believed that this info is not all true since the yelp and their menu both mention that they have wifi in the house. And if you are not having any internet service, how can you receive my online reservation order. I am totally not happy with my first time experience with MSOB or opentable. And now thanks to MSOB, my $20 promo is expired. 

By the way, the food is ok... Oyster is fresh... we ordered 4 for each oyster, totally 16 of them, but they all tasted pretty much the same to me. I was expecting a little bit of change from different type of oyster. Totally no surprise. For the Mission Fried Special, the calamine is not bad, moist enough and crisp at the same time. For the shrimp, they are a bit over done. And last but not least, the fried oyster, it is average. But overall this dish is a bit under season, add  a small amount of salt will help the favor of the plate.
author: V L.

description:
A solid oyster restaurant. 

A group of friends and I went here because I was craving oysters & seafood and that craving was definitely fulfilled. We ordered two dozen oysters for the table and they were all super fresh! There was tiny bit of shell in a few but other than that very nicely shucked! 

Their entrees were also very tasty and large! The cioppino was definitely a size for two. Seems like a standard dish offered at seafood restaurants in the bay area and although I'm not as familiar with it - it was very good and the garlic bread that came with it was amazing to dip the sauce in! We also ordered the spicy garlic prawns and this was also a very large dish and tasty. The prawns were cooked perfectly and the seasoning was right on. 

They seem to have pretty good happy hour deals so if I have the chance, I'd want to return for that.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
After spending the morning hiking at Lands End, my friend and I were on the hunt for oysters! We stumbled across this restaurant on Yelp and made the ~30 minute drive from Sea Cliff to the Mission District. Luckily, there was ample metered street parking and we snagged a spot directly in front of the restaurant. 

The staff was very friendly and welcoming. The restaurant was clean and neat but slightly chilly with the door left open.

My friend and I tried their fresh oysters at a price of $2 each. Unfortunately, their $1.50 happy hour deal does not apply to Friday. Nevertheless, the oysters were very delicious, though the horseradish was not very potent. 

We decided to share the Steamed Shell Fish Combination which was around $20. This was ridiculously good! It left the two of us satisfied and very stuffed. This dish included shrimp, clams, and mussels in a wonderful sauce. The sauce definitely made the dish. It was savory with a hint of sweetness. I'm not sure what ingredients were used in concocting this wonderful broth but there were tomatoes and a variety of fragrant spices. 

The total bill including tip for two people was around $40. As my friend and I were so full we could barely walk, it was very much worth the money!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Really good selection at the raw bar.  Updated daily specials for lunch and dinner.  The miyagis and kumamotos were among the best I've encountered.  $2 oysters all weekend long, including Fridays.  Decent array of alcohol.
author: David C.

description: Great oysters!!!!!  Great little find in the middle of a not so nice part of town.  Heard parking sucked so we too Uber.  Don't be alarmed by the area. You NEED to come here if you like oysters beer and wine!!   Great find for sure!!!  My  wife's and my new place for oysters in the bay!!  Staff are great friendly and fast getting food out to you.
author: Jamie S.

description:
I thought I didn't like oysters, but my friends brought me to this place and I was WRONG. 

The oysters were amazing and our fish special--crab staffed sole-- was cooked perfectly. The staff just could not have been nicer.
author: Dana B.

description:
Solid. Came here around 3pm on a Sat afternoon. The brunch rush left and there were no other guests. Odd, but it was beautiful outside so people were probably at Dolores park.  This place is pricy. Thankfully my sister was treating. Holler!

Spicy Shrimp - spicy, garlicky goodness. Veg were nicely done as well. 

Fish and Chips - The fries were cajun spiced fries. A great change up. However, the fish batter was GREASY. This happens when the oil is not hot enough to fry.  So that was a bummer. Only two pieces for $17. 

Crab cakes - delicious, expensive.

The mission deal - We got the full order. Oysters looked good from what my sister and her husband told me. I did not eat them for personally reasons. The steamed clams and shrimp were in a delicious garlicky wine broth.  

Overall: Very nice, relaxed interior. It's just located in a kind of hectic, "mission-y" (I hope you know what that means) spot between retail stores and Taqueria Cancun. Service was decent. Like I said, expensive but it's seafood and it's the mission.
author: William V.

description:
Came here for the happy hour and was definitely not let down.  There was only one other group in the establishment at the time and the bartender/waitress was attentive.  I did not catch her name.

They have changed their happy hour guidelines to say that each person can only have 12 oysters at happy hour price, typically a negative for a fat piece of shit like me but I somehow managed to score on a not fat piece of shit wife.  Double oysters for the win!

I also decided to get two each of the other more expensive, not happy hour oysters and those were also just as fresh and tasty.

I read a couple of reviews about the garlic bread and nobody is lying.  This is probably the best garlic bread out there.

I mean really, get the garlic bread....forget oysters...just get the bread.
author: Nick N.

description: Great food. Oysters are fresh and delicious.  Mmmmmm. Can't wait to come back. Service is fast and they are super friendly.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Doar M.

description: Took our young adult daughter there to celebrate her B-Day shortly before X-mas. She had been there several times with her friends. Great variety of fresh oysters reasonably priced. Clam chowder was of the right consistency - not watery and not too thick. Service was even on a quiet night. Would recommend eating there during off-peak period and not be rushed.
author: Smjoe F.

description:
went here last night with some friends that were visiting. Really enjoyed it a lot! They have a pretty extensive variety of oysters that are only $2 an oyster which is pretty cheap compared to some of the places around here. Portions are big too for the price you pay. I got the combo cocktail and house salad along with some oysters (French Kiss and Kukomoto). Very delicious and fresh tasting. My friends got the Cioppino, Prawns, Combo Salad, and one of the pastas. They did say the Cioppino was a bit salty but otherwise everything was really good. 

will be back!
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Went here yesterday for some oysters with my boyfriend. We were the only ones in the restaurant at the time (3:30pm). Ordered the Mission half special (6 oysters, 2 prawns, and some steamed clams), as well as a bowl of clam chowder. While the seafood was good quality (I especially enjoyed the clams!) and the price was decent, I was really let down by the service. We received our food, and since we were splitting the meal we finished in a pretty reasonable amount of time, and decided we wanted to order some more oysters.

We waited for 20 minutes with empty plates in front of us waiting for someone to come by our table so we could order the oysters. Nobody came to check up on us, refill our water, or bus our table. We tried to make eye contact with a member of the staff, but they were all in the back of the room talking amongst each other and not paying attention to the only customers in the restaurant. I would totally have understood the slow service if the restaurant was busy, but there were at least 4 people working and nobody came by or acknowledged us, which I thought was odd. My boyfriend and I decided that if it was going to take this long for us to get our table bussed, there was no use trying to order more food. So after another 10 minutes of waiting, our check comes, we paid and we left.

I would love to come back to this establishment, as I thought the quality of food was good. But if the service is going to be like this again, I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Lauren C.

description: Found this hidden place on yelp. Everything is okay, the prices are pretty high and the wait was excruciatingly long (1.5hrs). I love love raw oysters but I guess I can get that anyway around the bay. In all it was a place everyone should at least try but the deal breaker for me was everything is served and prepared by bare hands. That's a big turn off for me and wiping their hands on dirty aprons didn't help either :/
author: Jackie D.

description:
The evening was basically perfect: parking one block away (!), delicious oysters, and my boyfriend met us after so we could have some wine with dinner. My roomie and I were craving oysters by the dozen and headed over.

Nothing special inside, but clean and more family-friendly than the usual Mission restaurant. We sat at the bar and were quickly greeted by the bartender with water glasses and menus. We said we came for oysters so she explained each of the oysters on the menu. Decided to go with 6 Dutchboys and 6 Chesapeakes to start with. So good! The Dutchboys were sweet and plump, my favorite of all. We got another half dozen each of the Miyagis and the French Kiss. 

We split a bottle of Enohe (?) wine; I didn't choose it; I would normally go with a white to accompany my seafood, but it's not all about me, so I compromised. The wine was mild and nice, just not my first choice with oysters. A bit pricey for the wine if you ask me, but worth the happiness of my friend. In all honesty I wanted a dirty martini but they don't have a hard liquor liscence (though they have been there for over a year...).

The music was Latin and loud, enough for us to both comment on to eachother. I would have liked jazz or something more mellow. Some low booths would be nice to fill in the place and make it a bit more cozy. They could also use more adversiting/PR: I had never heard of this place until I Yelped for oysters in the Mission, and it was pretty empty for a Saturday night. I think if hard liquor was served they would get, yes, a different crowd, but probably more business on a weekend evening. Either way, a-okay in my book, I will definitely be back for happy hour.
author: Crystal C.

description: Awesome food. Great deals on oysters. $2 oysters on the weekends. Definitely recommend the spicy garlic prawns! Service was really great as well. We went in on Halloween, and thought it was great that they were giving out candy to trick or treaters while still tending to all the guests dining.
author: Joe G.

description: This was the best coippino we have had in San Francisco. It's not touristy tomato broth they serve in fisherman's warf. Seriously very good food. The staff was also friendly and attentive. We will definitely go back for that cioppino.
author: Thomas R.

description: Came during happy hour. Decent prices for oysters. $1.50 each. We also had the Crab Caesar salad which was really good.
author: Jacklyn T.

description:
Came here on a Friday for a dinner of 8. Two tv's at the bar to watch the game. Server was very friendly and accommodating. The busser continuously kept our tables clean and our water glasses full. Place is nestled on the mission but inside has a modern feel to it. Parking is street, so good luck.
Here's what we ordered:
3 full orders of mission special 
2 bottles of red wine
2 fried calamari 
2 orders of crab cake
Potato wedges 
Roasted garlic, white wine, fresh chopped tomato & basil pasta
3 Clam chowder bowls

We ate family style so we can all taste here and there. Everything was so delicious but that sauce for the clams and prawns in the mission special was amazing. We all wanted to drink the rest out of the bowl. Jokingly even wanted to ask for a container to bring the sauce home. The clam chowder was not watery. The pasta was pretty good and light but flavorful. They brought their A game that night.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
3 stars for the cioppino (minus the fact that there were 2 unopened mussels in it-dangerous, not cool). The dinner salad with creamy garlic dressing was also REALLY good. The clam chowder, though, was not very good. It wasn't very flavorful and there wasn't much of anything in it. Some tiny pieces of chopped up clam and a few tiny pieces of potato. 
The worst part though was the service. Our server was perky and nice when we walked in, but then things went downhill. My friend went to the bathroom and she asked for my drink order. When my friend came back she should have come right away and took her drink order but we waited a long time and I was half done with my drink while she had to just sit there with nothing. When we ordered she walked away without asking me what dressing I wanted on my salad so I assumed it was just a standard vinaigrette but the she came back a while later and asked. Overall she just kept walking into the back and not coming out for a really long time which was odd since there were by 2 tables and the other was already finished eating. 
My friend had more than half her cioppino left and she said "u done?" Not "would u like this to go?" So I asked for a to go container and she brought one to the table and slopped it into the container, getting it all over the sides and then used her fingers to wipe it off the sides. She also brought our drinks by holding the glasses from the part you drink from. She was just rude and had no idea about the basics of her craft. After we put money inside the check folder she came over immediately and said "u need change?" And we said no so she took the folder and walked away. So rude!!! If we don't need change then u leave it there. She was rude and inconsiderate and because of that we won't be back for the delicious cioppino.
author: Emma H.

description: Great selection of oysters for Happy Hour.  Love the quality and the decor of this place.  Love it. Love it.
author: Thomas L.

description: I recommend the specials especially the Cioppino. Wonderful wine pairing and convenient location.
author: Rachel S.

description: Had the calamare.  Old oil, coating tasted like bad cornmeal and it was similar to stuff from Costco.  If this is the best that Yelp can recommend,  I'll  quit using it.
author: Tom E.

description:
Delicious! Chowed down on 3 dozen of some of the freshest oysters here the other day...DEFINITELY worth the 10 block walk from bart during a blackout 

Even though this place was supposed to be a pre-dinner, appetizer sort of deal, we couldn't resist getting the clam chowder and bread. Kind of an overlooked thing, but they had absolutely AHHHmazing bread and butter...like I still cant get over what an unbelievable balance of crispy, soft, warm, buttery.....slllsslfjls *insert homer simpson drooling sound here* 

saw another table had ordered dungeness crab and it looked BOMB, but didn't have the stomach capacity. seems like a must try!
author: Debra L.

description:
This place is quite knowledgable on their oyster game! A little on the expensive side with their $2 oyster from Friday to Sunday, but they make it up with their ambience and their amazing entrées! 

Friday night around 8PM, a friend and I decided to try one of each of the listed oysters, and two of the supposedly best Konomoto oysters - small, but extremely creamy and flavorful. Our waitress was helpful in explaining the differences between all the oysters and recommended a few dishes as well. They oysters came and one by one we ate the biggest, or the least flavorful, to the smallest, the most flavorful. I have to say, it is true - the bigger oysters are typically more bland! If you all have a chance, definitely go for the Konomoto because I'm in love with it. I also love adding the vingerette provided, along with the lemon and and tapatio for an extra kick! Also, I recommend the house chardonnay with the oysters. It's a great match!

Moving on to the next appetizer - The Garlic Bread (capitalization to emphasize how amazing it was). I don't know what these guys do to their garlic bread, but it is literally the best I have EVER tasted. The outside is crunchy/cripsy and the inside is moist and soft. I believe they light buttered the bread and then layered slightly browned cheese on top. Then lightly sprinkled a bit of pepper, basil (?), and garlic powder. Everything just sort of melts in your mouth and leaves a slightly delicious garlic taste aftertaste. UGH. HEAVEN. It was so unexpected, but brilliant. The appetizer comes with about five large pieces; I'd say equivalent to the size of a iPhone 4S, possibly a tad longer and definitely wider.

Next was the Cioppino, which was taken from a yelp suggestion. It reminds me of a stew, but instead of vegetables, they use seafood. Using a tomato base, the restaurant adds a mixture of clams, muscles, shrimp and fish that blends well with the tomato broth. The sour tomato mixed with the sweet seafood gives the dish a slightly sweet, almost tangy flavor. I had no problem easily scooping out the contents of the seafood from the shells since it was quite soft. The shrimp does not have the shell, only the tail, which is easy to eat. It comes with two pieces of garlic bread, which I highly recommend dipping it into the sauce. 

Their seafood is obviously of high quality. However, they could work on their ambiance a little more. It's a dark and dimly lit restaurant that creates a cozy atmosphere. However, I noticed that because the building is so large, I could often hear and occasional echoing. With the light chatter from all the customers, I definitely think that the restaurant could turn up the music a bit as well. I did notice, and love, that each table is kind of in their own little bubble. It's definitely a more intimate environment and they always keep your water glasses filled - props!
author: Annie T.

description: Cioppino was super good, garlic bread was great, oyster selection is phenomenal and reasonably priced. Ambiance is pleasant and unassuming. Staff is very Friendly!
author: John D.

description: The chupino which was a special was excellent! Also you can't go wrong with $2 oysters on Saturday.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
I'm visiting SFO with my girlfriend and so we found this place on Yelp and headed over for dinner last night.

The warning should've been how empty this place was compared to all the other places in the neighborhood. Despite the lack of patrons, we were pretty hungry so we sat down and ordered pretty quickly.

My oysters were fine - nothing special and I probably could've paid the same at a nicer restaurant.  My girlfriends meal, however, was terrible. She ordered the ahi tuna steak with rice and vegetables.  The veggies looked and tasted like they came from a microwave pack - absolutely no flavor.  The rice was similar: terribly made, watery, and no flavor. The tuna itself looked like they quickly heated it up and poured the pesto sauce on - tasted like it too!

Aside from the quality of food we were also disappointed with the presentation; I'm not picky but the tuna steak was just thrown on the rice as if they were too rushed to set it on the plate; VERY sloppy.

While I don't live in SFO, I did share my experience with friends to make sure that they don't put too much weight on the four star yelp rating that they currently have.
author: Rayan D.

description:
First off...what is that rancid smell when you walk in? I'm hoping it's the cheese they use for their garlic bread or something but man does this place have a nasty funk to it.

Anyway, we got seated and we started off with a dozen oysters.  I honestly can't remember what we got but i think we said 2 of each on the list they had up.  Since I'm from Seattle and some of the oysters came from Washington I didn't think much of them.  They were good don't get me wrong but they didn't stand out.  

Since there were 4 of us we did it family style.

Ordered:

Garlic bread - THIS IS A MUST! Probably my favorite item that we ordered here.  Very good!

Spicy Garlic Prawns -  They were good.  A little salty but very garlicky and flavorful.  My kind of spicy garlic prawns minus the overdose of salt.

Steamed Clams - I don't remember these. Must've not been that eventful if I can't remember

Cup of Clam Chowder - You want to pass on this unless you like watery chowder.  Not my thing.

Side of Garlic Mash - Delish!

Service was mediocre.  Our server forgot we had other items coming out after our oysters and she came over to check on us like she was ready to give us our check.  Um sorry homegirl but we got more food coming.  You can't go home just yet.  The busser came by to clear up some dishes and ended up spilling water on our table and onto some of our shoes, pants etc.  No harm done since it was just water.

Would I come back? Probably not.  I'll check out Swan Oyster Depot since it's a few blocks from my sisters place.
author: Chau D.

description:
If you're craving good, fresh seafood, this is the place for you! I celebrated my birthday here a couple of months ago and I was so happy with the overall experience. I have been recommending it to all my friends. 

This place rocks! In terms of being able to accommodate a large crowd and managing to have all the food come out relatively the same time. The food was so delicious and not heavy. Sometimes, seafood places will load up on the butter making it really heavy. Here, the flavor were clean and light. It is very easy to over indulged here but it's so worth it! We were able to order a lot on the menu and everything we ordered was fantastic. The garlic bread is the bomb dipped in all the sauces! 

You can not go wrong with anything on the menu! I highly recommend this place!
author: Sara W.

description:
While I plan most of our vacations, I gave Doug the task of planning an evening all his own. I am so excited that he found this amazing little gem. 

They oysters were fantastic. Fresh, flavorful, and the perfect temperature. We were there during happy hour, so the prices were fantastic, as well. 

Great oysters paired with a fantastic beer and cocktail list and exceptional service... what more could you want? Definitely make sure you check this spot out if you are in the area. You won't regret it.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Review for the happy hour oysters! When we went on a Thursday, there were 3 types of oysters on the hh menu, so naturally we ordered one dozen of each :)

All of the oysters were fresh and tasty (and all uniform sized too!)...don't you hate it when they give you 1 or 2 that look half eaten!?

Large space, comfortable settings. I'll def come back.
author: Ames L.

description:
Oysters were great - even on a Sunday. Service was okay. It was hot in there which bothered me because the last thing I want to feel is HOT, inside a seafood restaurant. There were also flies in the dining room - enough of them to warrant a comment about it. Keep the doors closed and that may help to reduce the bugs. 

The Cioppino was delicious - the sauce was a heavier tomato sauce and not really a broth. But very tasty and the shellfish tasted fresh and delicious. The white fish that typically is overcooked in cioppino, was clearly added in at the end and it was not dry at all. The combo salad was great too. I saw the shrimp and mixed seafood cocktails go out to a different table and those looked amazing. I will definitely be going back here again! Nice, casual, relaxed atmosphere!
author: Emily C.

description:
Being from the South Bay whenever I come to the city I want a great seafood spot that isn't a tourist trap and that isn't ridiculous in price.  I think this place was perfect.

Although the neighborhood might put you off at first the food is well worth it.

Frutti di Mare: I absolutely love love loved! this dish! $30 which seems pricey but you can definitely split it with two people and it is LOADED full of seafood.  comes with two big pieces of delicious garlic bread to soak up the juice

clam chowder: it was good. nothing special or amazing but it was good.

seafood gazpacho: my mother ordered it, I am not a fan but I don't like cold seafood soups.  However my mother really enjoyed it.

great staff, very friendly and an added bonus, our waitress had an ipad full of pictures of all their dishes.  being a visual person I loved that and she had no problem standing there showing us as many dishes as we wanted until we made up our minds
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Last minute looked for a restaurant that had seafood in the area and we could not have stumbled on a better restaurant than this! Reasonable prices and great seafood menu. Oysters $2 every day or $3 for premium oysters. Well rounded drink menu. 

Started the meal off with one of the specials: a 1/2 baked artichoke, stuffed with Dungeness crab, bay shrimp, basil and some croutons... I'd come back to this restaurant just for this. Delicious. Perfectly balanced, mixture of textures, seasoning on point. 

Tried the house salad with a garlic italian dressing (not overly dressed) as well as a cup of clam chowder. Both equally delicious.

Finished the meal off with two orders of their garlic crab. Seriously fresh, sweet and delicious crab. Could not have asked for a better dish.

Only criticism is that there were no kid friendly items other than french fries. For that I'd deduct half a point, but truthfully the food was so good I may just have to feed our son before we go there the next time!
author: The Dreaded Critic S.

description:
My husband and I visited this restaurant excited to get stuck into a heap of oysters. Unfortunately after trying two oysters the third tasted really bad (as in dodgy, off, a likely food poisoning). I immediately spat it out and brought it to the attention of our server. The shell was a strange yellow colour and there were several others that looked equally questionable. The server wasn't particularly concerned despite the fact we were concerned. He brought back the oysters with a couple of replacements (another oyster that was questionable left uneaten) and no real explanation from the chef. The only explanation given was that he hates it when that happens!!! 

We requested the check (no offer of price reduction for bad food) paid and left. We didn't bother to order the rest if the meal as we were too disgusted and worried about food poisoning. There was no real apology or concern shown from the staff. Needless to say we won't be returning...

I will mention this visit was back in August. It took me a while to post. I would be appealed if they hadn't got their act together now and actually have staff that know the difference between a good and bad oyster seems it is their main product!
author: Erin D.

description:
This oyster bar had terrible service..and dare I say  even borderline racist! Yes, given we were the only Asian faces in a sea of white clams, no puns intended here, and let me just clarify that I've  never pulled out the race card before, but our server who was the tom boy looking white female  wearing a newsboy cap clearly showed more attention, friendliness, and more effort towards the white folks, while looking totally uninterested and apathetic when serving us. Now I do understand that they were fully packed and way understaffed for a 3 day weekend, but we noticed that when she was serving the plate of dozen oysters to the different tables, she would actually make effort to explain the different types of oysters and where they came from, but when she was serving us the oysters, she just abruptly dropped them on our table, without any acknowledgement or explanations of the oysters, and left quickly. Now, normally I would let that slide because I understand that she was super busy and that the huge party of 15 white folks to the left of us was far more important, but every time she served us, she clearly looked like she didn't give a crap, and when we asked why did she bring out just one bowl of clam chowder, when we actually ordered three bowls, instead of being apologetic or even throwing a corny joke, which would have been the professional way to handle it, she instead complained to us how she was the only server for the night, and that we would  just have to wait for her to bring it over. 

Now besides the lackluster service, with the exception of the Mexican bus boy who refilled our waters with a smile and would actually ask us if everything was okay.. I mean he was cool..the food was nothing spectacular. The dozen raw oysters weren't thoroughly cleaned since there were still some very small shell pieces in it and tasted flat and mediocre. 
Now on to the clam chowder...my wife makes a way better clam chowder than what we were served here! There was no rich creaminess of cholesterol heaven that you'll expect from a professionally well made clam chowder..I thought it kinda tasted like I was drinking a Campbell's soup can.
