The crab meat cocktail was not seasoned well and was lamely served with some cocktail sauce. The Prawn Alfredo was ok..but the prawns tasted frozen and the Alfredo sauce tasted like Italian amateur night.. almost very similar to what my 12 year old daughter can make at home. 
I can go on and bitch about the food more, but that'll just be a waste of my time..and your time reading it. Overall, we felt unwelcome, waited almost 40 minutes for just the appetizers to come out, and weren't  thrilled by the entrees at all. On the plus side, the bottle of house Chardonnay we ordered was quite good for like 25.00 a bottle... But then again.. You can't really fuck that one up.
author: Fontine D.

description: We went there around 3 pm and had a dozen oysters during happy hour. The oysters were really fresh and I loved the different choices that were recommended by our waiter. Our waiter was also extremely attentive and friendly. We wanted to order the prohibition ale but since they were out, he just poured out 3/4 of a glass and gave it to us for free. And who doesn't love free beer?
author: Anum H.

description:
The green lips are excellent
Great selection of fresh oysters 
Garlic bread tasty
Clam chowder thin base, any clams?
I'll keep coming back, I love this place!!!
author: Travis B.

description: Hands down, the worst meal and restaurant I have been to in my life. From the microwaved & tasteless fish, raw vegetables, and rude staff, it's hard to believe that this place is still in business.
author: Effie T.

description: We really liked this place. Went in about two weeks ago for HH oysters and drinks. Service was wonderful. Woman behind the bar was super sweet and personable. I can't remember her name but she was awesome.
author: Ashley G.

description: Well worth the walk from the hotel...I would suggest using Market and looping around as Mission is a sketchy walk.  Super fresh oysters and delicious spicy shrimp.  Hubby loved the garlic dungeoness crab....
author: Jillian S.

description: We wanted to try a different restaurant that served seafood in the city specifically oysters.  We tried all the oysters, the variety was great and and they where fresh. The place is definitely casual and low key. The food was good but service was a little slow and there was only 2 other tables. I would not consider this place a $$ because it was pretty pricey for the location.
author: Juan T.

description: Go to this place! Seafood is amazing and the servers are happy and helpful! We enjoyed happy hour oysters, stuffed sole, seafood pasta and seafood salads. All were perfectly delicious, served in a no nonsense space. Going back to try their highly rated cioppino. Can't wait!
author: Mary M.

description: This place is great! My boyfriend and I have been here multiple times for their cippino. Everything has good flavor and it's not ridiculously expensive. I felt as though the service there was really good. They're friendly and absolutely will help you out if you're having trouble deciding what to get. This is a place I'll happily continue going to.
author: Briahna E.

description: I see the great reviews so I am hear about this review from its fans. But really - i made a reservation and there's no place to check in. The service was inconsistent and slow...even though they were nice. But the server I think had too many tables. But most importantly the food was not good. My fish and chips batter tasted like donuts! My friends seafood pasta special was very salty. We won't be back.
author: Kevin T.

description:
(not so) Happy hour starting at 3pm. My friend and I got there at 2:30pm, decided to kill some time and ordered clam chowders. $5 for probably the worst clam chowder I've ever had. Worse than the canned kind and the buffet kind combined. I'm talking bland, watery, uncooked vegetables, no clam, clam chowder. We sat there and waited until 3pm to order those damn oysters...

People start filing in, but we got our order in before everyone else did. We watched all the groups around us get their orders and still... no oysters. BTW, this place shouldn't be called an oyster bar if they don't shuck open those shells in front you. Either way, it took forever to get the oysters, they only have 3 types, but the oysters are good, especially the local one. 

Oh yeah, the servers really suck at pouring draft beers. Literally 1/3 of the cup is filled with foam.. and they are really really slow too. Understaffed for sure.
author: Jessica L.

description: Great variety of dishes to choose from. A little bit pricey but worth every penny. I had the mixed plate with  baked scallops and prawns with mashed potatoes and oh man it was so good. I also ordered a Shirley Temple which was not in the menu, but they still accommodated to my order. Most definitively will come back to this place.
author: Dash B.

description: Rockefeller was good. I don't like row oysters but I liked the baked ones. Kinda pricy. It wasn't crowded at all considering it was Friday night. But over all it was good.
author: Tsubomi N.

description:
LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD Soooooo loud I could not carry on a conversation across the small table.  First off, the crowd was like that at a sports bar during a major game.....LOUD!  The high ceiling makes the sounds of voices, dishes being placed down, glasses clanging, etc. amplified to an absurdly loud level.  We arrived when the place was half full and it was already questionable.  By the time we left it was about 80% full and so damn loud that I found myself nearly screaming across the table.  We both gave up trying to converse and hurried through our meal just to get out of there.  When we left my ears felt like I had just left a dance club.  We walked up and down Mission.  Every other place was quieter, even the full bars! 

Food:  Best ciopinno I've had in SF.  Garlic bread was very good too, but not the best I have had.  Raw oysters were fresh but tiny.  Oysters Rockafeller were a joke!  All it consisted of was the same happy hour small raw oyster with the garlic spread across it and placed under a broiler for a few seconds.  At $3.50 each it was insulting for a morsel as small as my thumb nail.  This was NOT oysters Rockafeller by any standard.  Service was friendly and attentive.

If you are adverse to a loud echoing room clinging with the sounds of plates and glasses coupled with patrons all screaming across the tables just to be heard then stay away.  You will hate it.  If you love ciopinno and want to have one of the best then come here during the off hrs when no more than 3 tables are occupied and enjoy it......good luck finding those circumstances though.  

Overall, given the alternatives in SF many of which are mentioned in the other reviews I'd say skip it. 

PRICE:  Oh, and the prices are not cheap either.  We split one entree, had half a dozen oysters, one glass of their cheapest wine and a half order of garlic bread.......really just about what one person might order.....total was $72!!!  One entree, a drink, bread and an appetizer in the mission at a very casual seafood place.....NOT a good value no matter how you slice it.

SMOKING---They leave the door and front windows open so that everyone walking by smoking might as well be seated at your table.  It gets really bad of the smokers stand right outside or by the store fronts next door.  Trust me.....they do!  If you are adverse to cig. smoke I'd stay away.  Eventually they closed the door and windows but each time the door was opened, which was frequently with all the people coming and going, the smoke immediately outside was sucked in.  Gross!!
author: John B.

description:
Mission Street Oyster Bar is a nice casual break from the hustle and bustle of the Mission.  The restaurant itself is very minimalistic and not overpacked with seating leaving the ambiance with a spacious, yet calming feel with slate blue walls adorned with ocean themed accessories.  I love the colorful marlin on the wall!

My bf and I ordered the full order of 12 raw oysters, four prawns and steamed clams for $32.95.  We ended up with yummy, fresh Chesapeake and Miyagi oysters which satiated our raw oyster craving.  The steamed clams came with four prawns and were a real buttery delight!  -perfectly cooked shrimp and nuances of flavors in the broth!  A pleasant woman with short hair who tended to us the whole time sold us on the garlic bread.  Great suggestion!  That was probably the best garlic bread we had ever indulged in!  It was regular French bread with butter, paprika, parsley, garlic and some cheese on top.  I think it was Monterey Jack.  It was the perfect addition to the steamed clams and frankly would be to anything brothy here.  Sorry no hard liquor here, but there is a decent selection of beers, IPA and wine.  They even have soju here.

I really can't say what could be better despite the casual atmosphere which is comfortable.  The prices are right.  The food is excellent, and the service is on point!  What a great find for raw oysters close to home.  We shall be back!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Great service, great oysters, and no wait at 5:00 on a Saturday. Those oysters, though...they have such a wide variety (I think 5 when we went) and they are all delicicously fresh and salty. 

Just go for the oysters, though. The green mussels and shrimp dish the boyfriend tasted a little rubbery, and my crabcakes tasted like they were more breadcrumbs than crab. 

Would definitely go back for the oysters!
author: Claire S.

description: I really enjoyed my first raw oyster experience!!! It was not only cheap (happy hour) but they had a great selection. I recommend Chesapeake oysters. And I was given water without asking...
author: Simone J.

description:
Their Happy Hour is a favorite of mine. Fresh, clean, luscious oysters for $1.50 with some damn decent beer or wine pairings. I LOVE it. That pretty much goes for all their seafood. Go for their Cioppino, you will not regret it. Ask for a side of regular bread and butter to use for dippage. It comes with their Garlic Bread, but for me it's got too much going on (Parmesan and garlic pieces). 
Mel usually helps me pick an oyster. She knows her stuff.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Maybe it's not fair of me to write a review because I didn't sample all of their dishes and certainly not a house speciality.

The place is easy to miss, on a dark and dingy section of Mission a bit down from Cha Cha Cha and some other hipper spots. Inside is clean and nice, small (I'd recommend maybe a reservation if it's a peak time, as there aren't many tables) but I had no trouble being seated solo at 7:15 on a Monday. 

I was only in the mood for a small cup of clam chowder, which I saw other reviews saying was absolutely amazing here, so I decided to order that and the bread & butter to sop it up.

Slow service--- my waiter was overwhelmed by a huge, rowdy party against one wall and a few smaller tables that were splitting his attention. He brought me a water glass (no ice, water was tap-temperature) and then took him about 10 minutes to take my order and another 15 or so to bring it out. Three slices of bread were toasted crusty, slightly burned on the top but nothing inedible, but had no flavor and the butter was just wrapped little pats. Not worth $2.50. 

The chowder was thinner than I'd expected and very few clams, mostly potato that I could taste. Good flavor overall but bland; tasted, to be frank, like Campbell's clam chowder. Not what I was expecting. Needed some seasoning for sure, and more clams in it--- tasted like I was eating watery cream of potato soup.

My bill came to about $8, waiter dropped it off and after waiting about 7 minutes he never came back to pick it up so I just left cash (with his tip) and headed home.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Came here for lunch, super excited about their oyster deal. However... the oysters were properly cleaned, lots of shells and sand in them. Fresh, but not pleasant to eat. 

Other dishes are way too pricey, I guess that makes up for the inexpensive oysters.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I really enjoy their happy hour and fish & chips. 

The staff is friendly, it's clean, and the quality of the food justifies the prices.
author: Hector M.

description:
Came here for my first seafood fix in SF
I ordered the mission combo (which came with oysters, clams and prawns)
It was VERY delicious. Oysters were great and plump. The prawns that came in a buttery wine sauce were huge! 
I ordered garlic bread so that I could dip it in the white wine sauce yummmm

The only con to this establishment was the rude 20-something waitress I had. No thank yous, never checked up to see how my table was doing, and slammed dishes on the table. 

Although the food is great (I would give 4.5 stars for), I wouldn't come back for the rude service. I'm sure I can find just as good food for better service.
author: M C.

description:
Sorry Woodhouse, I've found a new place for aphrodisiacs. 

I read about Mission Street Oyster Bar's daily happy hour from 3-6 pm ($1 oysters and $2.50 draft beer.) SOLD! 

Y'know how some deals are TOO good to be true? Well, MSOB is the real deal. Oyster selections change daily and on our first dining experience, we chatted with the chef/owner, Freddy. Freddy's an affable and knowledgeable guy. After mentioning my penchant for Kumamoto oysters, he surprised us with two on the house. Creamy sweet delight! 

We tried three varieties of  fresh oysters (eastpoint, miyaki, and pacific inlet). Each type of oyster had its own distinct characteristics and the best part was that everyone in our group liked different ones (which only shows that taste is indeed subjective). 

We stopped for happy hour and stayed for dinner.  Service is excellent and the food is delicious. Highly recommend the spicy garlic prawns and the garlic crab (the white wine sauce is delicious).

Note: During our visit, MSOB was opened for a week so Freddy's working out the kinks typical of any new business. For example, the menu had misspellings which gave us a few laughs.
author: Sophie C.

description: Stumbled across this place and was pleasantly surprised. Food is amazing, and decent selection on the menu!
author: Danny E.

description: Reviews in this restaurant definitely not accurate. Oyster are no flavor. You can tell the calamari is frozen cause it doesn't taste fresh. And the Happy hour Rose does not taste like Rose, it tastes like Pinot with red color pigment.
author: Maggie L.

description:
I've walked by this place many times and never been, always thinking I should try it. We stopped by on Wednesday for dinner, and there was no wait for 4 people (by no wait, no mean no one in the restaurant-which I find surprising). 
The prices are a bit on the high side, but the portions are big and the food was delicious. We shared the mission special (12 oysters, 8 clams and 4 prawns). The clams and prawns were in this delicious white wine garlic sauce.  They even brought us bread to duping the yummy sauce!
We the got the spicy garlic shrimp, which was amazing (I loved the meatiness of the prawns)! And the cioppino -which was huge, with so much great seafood. It was a different base than a regular cioppino, but man was it tasty (with really good chunks of fish, crab, a few different kinds of mussels -two really big meaty ones which were great, clams, shrimp, etc). The garlic bread was also fantastic. 

To top it off, the service was really great! Our waiter was really patient and attentive.  He had good recommendations and was very nice!
author: Sarah F.

description: Caesar crab salad was delicious.  Bread served with meal was outstanding.  Very large meals.  Prices are somewhat high but not for San Francisco.  Oysters for $2 on Sat & Sun were very fresh.  Overall the meal was worth the drive.  Neighborhood is very eclectic and a bit dirty but that's SF for yah!
author: Jaymie T.

description:
We stopped in while waiting for a table across the street and realized we'd stumbled upon a gem. 

Finally a quality, casual spot to grab food in the mission --and without a line out the door. Not to mention, they're serving something different. You wont find "New American" food in a reclaimed wood and iron atmosphere here. This is what you hope every west coast tourist seafood spot will be like. Mission Oyster Bar is comparable to a classic east coast seafood joint. Nothing fancy folks, It's got the casual walk-in atmosphere that encourages a quick oyster and a beer, or a large group looking to eat a full meal and get their seafood fix without trekking over to North Beach or needing reservations in the FiDi. Get your cioppino, fresh oysters, shrimp, beer and wine at cafe tables. OH, and yum, the cheesy garlic bread  dipped in their sautéed muscles. 4 stars instead of 5 only because the service could have been a bit better.

Welcome, Mission Oyster Bar, I will be back very soon.
author: Betsy F.

description:
Great oysters!

Went in there on a random Wednesday, not another soul in the house. Totally weird, we got nervous...

BUT, no problems what so ever. Oysters we're great, clams were great, bread was great. The waitstaff - little weird and not really attentive. Screwed up our oyster choices, but we just are them.

Decor is weird and impersonal. Feels like a crappy Chinese place. 

But, if you don't want haul ass all the way to the wharf, they've got a good selection of oysters.
author: Blake W.

description:
This one we just sort of tried because it was in the right place at the right time.
Atmosphere could use some attention (no table clothes, but nice enough) but the service and the food was fantastic.   Good sized portions (we took part home), and very attentive service with good prices.    It was some of the best Cioppino I've had in a town famous for the dish.

On Mission between 18th and 19th.   Easy to get a reservations - I think the hipsters are afraid to venture over from Valencia.   Their loss.
author: Whitney D.

description: I know, I know, when in Rome... No, I didn't get oysters. I just happened to be craving fish and chips. The fish was a bit dry and bland, and it came with two small pieces of fish. It was garnished with a pinch of spring mix, a small carrot, and a tiny olive. At least the chips were good. All this for $18. I know, right? Wasn't impressed with the clam chowder either. Oh well.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Overpriced!! Food was good but not worth what we paid. $100 for a mediocre dinner for 2. And we didn't even order drinks or dessert! Service was bad as well. Only 4 tables seated in the restaurant and the waitress forgot to put our order in. Not coming back here.

Edit: changed this review to one star. Got home and realized they put all our left overs mushed together in one box. I don't need French fries on top of my pasta, thanks. What if one of us had a food allergy!? Terrible service!
author: Jen F.

description: If you love establishments who care about their product and customers. You must come here. I've had the Spicy Garlic Shrimp so far and you can taste the love! Go here without hesitation!
author: Jason C.

description: Came here for oyster happy hour. My sister and I split 16 oysters, 4 of each of different kinds. I forget the names, but there was a local one, and three from the Washington area. The local one was too salty for our tastes, but the Washington ones were fruity and champagne-y and really nice. The waitress who helped us was really nice and allowed my sister to bring in her bike to the back. They have these really good oyster crackers for soups at the table, which we obviously snacked on. Kind of a hard find in the middle of mission street, but no complaints about the happy hour. Nothing too special however.
author: Jefferson L.

description: Food was definitely good here.  I really didn't have a love for oysters until I visited this place.  I was introduced to some very sweet and succulent oysters.  The oysters are local, as well from neighboring states.  My recommendation, try the different types that they have to offer.  Interestingly so, they all have a different texture and taste profile to them (sorry if I'm preaching to the choir).  Now for the main dish, I tried one of their specials, which was the crab stuffed sole.  Cooked to perfection, fish was nice and moist, amazing peppercorn sauce on top, served with the most velvety mashed potatoes ever.  My friend had their other special, which was the lobster and prawn.  Once again, delish!!  Seafood was sauteed in a wonderful buttery chile sauce, which gave it a little bit of a kick.  Would highly recommend trying their specials, and ordering the garlic bread to dip all the good sauces with.  Parking, not so hot.  Service... I feel that there were not enough servers for the place, which resulted in a little delay with everything.  Also, when it comes to reservations, they don't really keep up.  So my advice would be to get there about 30mins early, let them know you have a reservation so they can start getting the table ready, and hang out at the bar.  Also, neighborhood is a bit sketch, so go with company, and don't stay out to late in that area.  Enjoy!!
author: Mijung H.

description:
Restaurant is clean and attractive. Service was good (special thanks to the bus boy....who was very attentive). Food..fair....hummm....missed opportunity.  Generous portions of wonderful, fresh seafood.....cooked in bland sauces :-(

Ordered: 
crab cakes-arrived overcooked  C
Seafood appetizer in tomato broth and avocado -looked great, but no flavor C
Frutti Del Mar- beautiful fish presentation, flavorful, very good B
Cioppino- beautiful fish presentation, but light on flavor B
Bread excellent...

At end of day....great seafood with underwhelming cooking skills. 
Didn't order oysters so no comment there.
author: Sharine d.

description: The happy hour oysters are now $1.50. It's still very fresh and delicious oysters! The best oysters in the city!
author: Tia O.

description:
Awesome food. Oysters were great.  Come here before the hipsters and yuppies discover it.
Yelp says I must write a longer review. Not sure what they expect.
author: Cris R.

description: Ok place food was eh good, my bar is high so its a five out of 10 it was not crowded but the staff seemed sullen we ordered and the place was not jumping it was afternoon.I'm giving for cleanliness stars but next time will pick something else. still in February but need exciting food
author: Keria B.

description:
Aphrodisiacs aside, this location certainly has a good selection of oysters! 
When my other half and I made our most recent venture here, we tried a selection of six oysters (2 each) for 12 total: Somerset, Brinier, French Kiss, Shikugo, Miyagi, and Kusshi. Favorites are all subjective; mine was absolutely the Shikugo, with the right balance of texture and flavor! Liked Somerset and French Kiss, too. Miyagi was good but thick. Thought the Brinier was a tad salty, and the texture of Kusshi was too rough for me, but it all was very interesting to taste a hint of the "oyster scope."

We also had prawns with tartar sauce dip, as well as a fried calamari/oysters mix. All tasted pleasant, up to par. Best thing about the place, though, are their titular oysters.

I do like that right on the menu, they list their wifi network.
author: Garett T.

description: Came here for my birthday because I was craving oysters. Man this spot is oddly placed in the Mission. You'd never expect a spot like this here. So basically all I wanted to eat on my birthday were oysters and french fries. We just missed happy hour so oysters were not a dollar anymore. We ordered a dozen oysters, a plate of fish and chips, garlic bread, and two beers. Why our bill was almost a hundred IDK lol. Nonetheless, the food was good. Definitely a spot to check out if you're in the area.
author: Dara S.

description:
LOVE this place!! When I moved to SF I promised myself not to eat at the same place more than twice (so many great places to explore!) Well- had to break my rule for this one!! 
The Cioppino is amaze-balls, and the bread served with it is as well! Had fresh Dungeness crab last time, and was also amazing.
Friendly staff, not crazy crowded- just a great meal, good price and good people!
author: Steven H.

description: Yeah, this is some good shit. Been here about half a dozen times over the past year and the food does not disappoint. Oysters are always fresh and delicious. My favorite thing on the menu is the crab Caesar salad. Wow!!! So much crab!!! Definitely worth the price. The garlic bread is a must. And always start with a cup of clam chowder with fresh cracked pepper. Mission Street Oyster Bar really is a hidden gem in this city.
author: Maya S.

description: Oysters are so fresh, and I believe this is the  freshest place in SF. They are not so crowded.
author: Chisa C.

description: Poorly shucked oysters and out of the first two beers we asked for on Tap. Now we know why this place was deserted when we arrived.
author: Anne C.

description:
I made a reservation here for a small weekend get away from Los Angeles. 

The one thing I will say, that other have said, there is a smell in there. But that doesn't bother me at all, the food I was eating didn't smell at all.

Second the neighborhood is a bit sketchy, but the ambiance inside was great and the prices were reasonable.
The clam chowder and garlic bread were fantastic and the oysters (we orders 3 dozen) were great! 

The service was great and I would come again, just goes to show, you should judge a book by its cover. Plus, if you're still hungry, there is a taco place next door. :)
author: Danielle S.

description:
great service, low key atmosphere, local joint. Went there with a couple of friends, nothing crazy special on the menu but right pricing.
We got crab cakes and oysters, both are sure choices.
author: Nicolas R.

description:
Wretched service and it wasn't busy. There was an HOUR wait after we ordered soup + bread + oysters... (foods that don't require any prep.) The food quality and taste were mediocre at best. The chowder could've been from a can cause there were barely any clams. When they finally plopped the oysters down in front of us, she left immediately without telling us anything about them.

They forgot 2 of our orders and when we addressed their mistake, the waitress didn't apologize. When we asked if they could maybe comp our appetizer for making us wait so long and forgetting our orders - she ignored us. Classy. 

Never coming back here.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Great place for Oysters and Seafood. Everything was extremely fresh and delicious. The food is not overly fussy...just amazing seafood. Prices are portions are extremely reasonable.

I will definitely be back!
author: Katie S.

description: We ordered three dozen Kumomotos, French Kiss, and Kusshi oysters were so good! The big crab was huge and delicious! Also good service.
author: Elena G.

description:
Visiting SF from Socal with the parents for the wknd. Came here for lunch. The 3 of us shared the Mission Special full order, cioppino, and a few fresh oysters. We all loved it. My super-particular Asian mama said the food quality & freshness was A-1!! :)
Service & oldies music were also awesome. This place was a gem in a kinda Blah neighborhood, so have patience finding a parking spot & come here!
author: Audrey G.

description: Really good place quite and relax !!! Great service ! And the price is about the average but their are worth it !!!
author: Yorka P.

description: The menu looks like basic oyster house fare but everything is prepared with a creative twist. Their cioppino is superb. We'll be back.
author: Bob M.

description:
Mixed emotions about this place overall cause sadly, it could be so, so much more than what it is.

First things first - as soon as we walked in, we debated walking out.  The entire place had a strange funky smell in it.  Old seafood?  Backed up sewer?  We couldn't place our noses on it.  We did push on knowing that we'd most likely get used to the smell (we did) and we were hell bent on eating oysters.   

The seafood was actually good.  Lesser than Bar Crudo, or Anchor Oyster Bar, but solid overall.  Nothing fancy, but seafood done right.  We ordered oysters on the half shell (3 dozen), Cioppino, and a Baked Sole entree.  Oysters & Cioppino were great - the Cioppino heavy with seafood.  Negative stars for their entree.  It came with the most uninspiring side of mashed potatoes and vegetables I've eaten.  The veggies tasted as though they were cooked in a pan full of burnt Teflon.  Bad.  Really bad.  

Overall, the ambiance of the place is poor.  It's just cheap tables and chairs.  That's pretty much it.  I don't have issues with such a cheap set-up in and of itself, it's just that if you're committing to a $260 dinner for a party of 4, you expect more.  You certainly don't expect the place to stink like poopy feet. 

The prices are the same, if not more than other casual seafood places in the city.  That's just wrong for what the place is overall.  Go to Woodhouse, go to Anchor, go to Bar Crudo, go to Hogs & Rocks, go to Swan Oyster Bar.  Don't go here.  Just don't do it unless you're in the hood and looking for some oysters for lunch.  I simply can't say it's worth it for any other reason.
author: Shawn S.

description: Great place to get beer and oysters! I always make a stop when in the mission. Their happy hour prices are great. The staff are pleasant. It's location is prime, close to other mission sites.
author: Eli D.

description:
This Oyster Bar had been on my list for, like, ever but its location kept pushing me away. Not that I don't like Mission, I love Mission. Food in Mission is fab but parking in Mission is a biatch.
But since it was raining this morning, my bf and I figured that everyone would rather stay in and order for a delivery and parking shouldn't be a problem, so we came here. 
The ambience is pretty contemporary; not as fancy as Water Bar, not as touristy as Swan Oyster Depot, but it looks just fine. The staffs were super nice.
We ordered 24 $1 oysters which were very fresh and briny. They offered 5 kinds of fresh oysters to choose from, which is a better deal than Water Bar that only offered a small miyagi one. Potato Wedges were paprika-ish and crispy. Very Nice.
This place will be a keeper for $1 oysters for me!
author: Joelle K.

description: Go for Happy Hour!  Love that they have 4 different types of oysters for you to choose from, not just one like most happy hour places.  Haven't tried their regular food, but if you're an oyster fan give this place a try.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I love this place and will be visiting many times in the very near future. 

I wanted to try something new in the area, and called in an order for Spicy Garlic Shrimp. I spoke with the chef, Angel, and he was fantastic. He explained the dish, and it was clear to see that he was very passionate about his food. I was blown away by the size of the shrimp and they were not over-cooked in the slightest!

I went back, literally, the very next night for round two. I asked for whatever was most fresh, and I got a delicious spicy cod. It had the perfect amount of spice and lemon. I am very glad that I found this place and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a great meal that isn't overprice.  I can't wait to try the cioppino. 

This is my first review, ever, on Yelp, and I am proud it's for this place. Enjoy!
author: Mark P.

description:
Went here with a group and was wildly unimpressed. I don't hand out bad reviews often, but this was a warranted low mark effort.

Overall a 1-2 star experience. Overpriced mediocre food, poor service and an uninspired atmosphere. At $23-28 per entree, this is one of the most over priced eateries in the mission.

The crab cakes were soggy and without the cocktail sauce would have been flavorless. The sole stuffed with crab was over cooked, dry and heavily salted. The calamari batter was bland. All in a low effort from the kitchen.

On the service side, things were pretty bad. I won't go into specifics for everything but a microcosm of the evening was the waitress took our forks following the apps and when entrees were delivered we asked for more forks - she proceeded to then go to 2 other tables to take orders. So as our food sat there getting cold without utensils to eat, she was taking drink orders.  I wanted 10 mins and then had to go to the kitchen myself to get forks for the table.
author: Justin O.

description:
In town for a conference and was committed to finding a crab dinner.  After much searching through various sites, decided to give this place a try.  The crab was delicious, and so happy that we made the trek out to this restaurant.   

Service was great - very nice attentive waitstaff, never had to resort to waving arms in the air for attention.  Checked in with us, but no hovering. I hate hovering.

We had the crab dinner special - an entire crab - probably around 2 pounds, was presented cut into eighths and served with a garlicy butter sauce.  It was so good, I ate every single morsel.   The meal was served with a nice green salad to start.   We ordered the garlic bread, and it was great.  

Dinner for two with a bottle of wine came to $120 and we both left feeling that the meal was worth it.
author: Maria C.

description: Wow... Great food, great service. Oysters on the half shell were varied and cold. The calamari was lightly floured and flash fried. While the garlic bread is super by itself, try putting a fresh oyster on a piece, then add the toppings you like. Wow again!
author: John D.

description:
Atmosphere was great. A little bit short staffed as well, but nothing noticeable.

Giving a poor rating here because I got the Mission Special (12 oysters + shrimps) and ~half of the oysters tasted either bland or simply bad. Same thing for my friend who ordered 6 oysters a la carte. For the price (and the restaurant name), I would have expected a certain level of freshness from oysters. 

All in all, disappointing, especially since I had great hopes coming in.
author: Francois C.

description: Best Cioppino I've had in my life so far. The portions were generous too.Will definitely come back here next time I visit the Bay Area. Can't wait to try out everything on the menu...oh and the 1.50 happy hour oysters were definitely an added bonus!
author: Mai B.

description:
The food was decent but the service was lacking. The waitress was obviously newly trained, but she didn't have answers to questions like how many prawns are in the prawn cocktail? We went on a Tuesday night and it was pretty much nobody but us. Not sure why. Maybe because there was a Giants game on which by the way they lost that night, but thank goodness they are in the NLDS! 
Anyway, I also thought they were quite overpriced. 
I might give them another try, we'll see.
author: Erin L.

description: GREAT OYSTERS from Washington state are served here. The oysters tasted so fresh and still tasted like they came out of the ocean. YUM! the cioppini was sooo delicious too and I am not really a fan of tomato based sauces. Our waitress was great and knew her oysters! The restaurant was kind of in a bad area (lots of loitering) but thank goodness the oysters made up for it......highly recommend!
author: Aline D.

description: My co-workers met me here for my send off and I can't put in words how good there happy hour specials are. Especially the $1 oysters, fresh and yummy.
author: Chris B.

description:
Went here on a Friday night. 

The place was accommodating of our large group but the oysters were only ok and way overpriced. 

We split a bunch of oysters and none of them were particularly good to be honest.  Had to ask my waiter for water multiple times before finally going to the bar and asking someone there.

The non-oyster food was disappointing too.  

Best aspect was that roomy tables separate far apart so you dont feel cramped, but just medicore overall..
author: Charles S.

description: Great find. Casual seafood restaurant on Mission. Excellent oysters, garlic bread and an amazing garlic Dungeness crab dish. Simple excellent seafood. Worth a visit. We will be returning.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I love it!  I've been an Anchor Oyster Bar customer for over 20 years,  and it's terrific.  But much of that time Fredy Gamez was back in the kitchen preparing my food, and his new place is bigger,  nicer . . . with a friendly and helpful staff . . . and the same great food at a better price. 

$1 oysters on the half shell from 3 to 6pm Monday through Thursday and $2 oysters all day Friday through Sunday.  Draft and bottled beer for $4 any time.   

I had his signature cioppino, and it was loaded with jumbo shrimp, Dungeness crab, clams, 2 types of mussels, calamari and succulent sea bass . . . in a slightly spicy tomato sauce that was perfect for dipping toasted cheese/garlic bread. It was enough to share. 

You just don't get this quality in the Houston area or very many places in San Francisco for that matter!
author: Jack L.

description:
Came here after work with some colleagues for oyster shooters/happy hour. The location was a bit weird, it's a pretty nice place (also, I did not need a reservation haha), smacked dab in the middle of some not so nice looking stores (but I guess that's gentrification for you).

The things that I remembered were: 1) service was great; 2) I'm not a fan of oysters haha; and 3) this man ate maybe 700+ oysters in one sitting?! They have his photo up in their "Hall of Fame" and gosh, I feel a mixture of admiration and disgust for him haha.
author: Christina C.

description:
Hands down the worst seafood restaurant I've EVER visited!

Before I even mention the food, service, etc...I have to say:

WTF?!?!?! THERE'S A PIGEON INSIDE THE RESTAURANT!! CLOSE THE DOOR!! THEY DIDN'T DO ANYTHING TO RID THE PLACE OF THAT PIGEON, AND WE DINED THE ENTIRE TIME WITH THAT BIRD WALKING AROUND US. (I'm sure this breaks a few health codes!)

Service was horrendous! We came in, and the bus boy "greeted" us by showing us our table, handing us our menu, and then walking away. In writing, this sounds normal, but his tone was completely monotonous and disinterested. He seemed confused when I told him we had a reservation, despite there being a couple open tables...he didn't really seem willing to help "serve" us.

It took quite a while before the waitress actually came by. It was "busy" (PLEASE...not even) enough that she didn't notice two people entering the restaurant to dine at their restaurant. Oh well...

The food was horrible. I'm always very weary about dining at seafood restaurants, normally because they are WAY overpriced or horrendous quality...or both!

We ordered the half order of their Mission Special (6 oysters, bowl of clams, and 2 shrimp), their fried calamari, and their Garlic Bread.

For their Mission Special, yea...the half order gives you 2 shrimp (ok...). We chose a couple of types of oysters, and the waitress got our order wrong (mixed up the types). They were fresh, but at the same time I just prayed we wouldn't get sick.

The clams weren't special, and the sauce was ok. The shrimp...big enough I guess.

My advice on the fried calamari...NEVER ORDER THIS...EVER!! THE WORST FRIED CALAMARI I'VE EVER EATEN!! You know those plastic bands people wear around their wrists? Think about chewing (eating) them, wrapping in "batter" which barely was present. Oooh, you could tell these were probably frozen at some point. Definitely NOT fresh, nor tasted anywhere close! We didn't finish our order.

A highlight (after all we ate...definitely a saving point) was our garlic bread. Really warm and cheesy and soft - loved dipping it in the clam sauce. Amused that out of all the seafood we had, only the bread was good. Sad...

How much did all of this cost, you might be wondering? $45...yup, such a rip-off!

It completely baffles me how this place gets a 4 star rating. I feel tricked into coming here. It's not even hype, it's just a surprising occurrence that people have rated this place so highly.

NOT COMING BACK!! I'd rather get fat off fast-food than come back here again!!
author: Kevin J.

description: Visiting from Texas during my honeymoon found this place on thrillist. Awesome oysters. Super friendly and very knowledgable staff who are more than willing to explain each on down to every detail. Great service. Whenever I'm in San Fran again I will def come back!
author: Oscar A.

description:
I spent $34.00 on 3 crab cakes.  The restaurant was so noisy and the customers were out of control.  The plate had french fries, 2 strean beans, 1 broccoli, and 2 pieces of cauliflower.  You could not eat the vegetables as they were very much undercooked.  The server never followed up to ask how my food was 

NEVER AGAIN
author: john h.

description: Very nice!  I love that you can get a reservation online, that's always great.  Cioppino was delicious--a rich, flavorful broth that was filled with lots of seafood, a good variety too.  The garlic bread is addictive, I had to exercise self restraint not to ask for more slices to soak up the broth.  Service was super friendly and efficient, exactly as it should be.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I guess it would be unfair to compare this place to Anchor Oyster, but the chef/owner's claim-to-fame was working there for 20 years before opening this place, so I will say this cannot really compare:  the overall ambiance of the place is odd (very modern-looking space and paint colors, tacky fish netting hanging up with sea shells and starfish hanging from them, a giant swordfish wall hanging, and random paintings you would buy from Ikea).  It's also very loud and echo-y.  And there are at least 8-10 ceiling fans going, even at night when it's already chilly out to begin with.

The service was good.  Our waitress was attentive and friendly, so no complaints there.

The food itself was just okay.  The fish itself was cooked okay, but definitely not worth the price.  Also, my dining partner and I ordered different entrees, but they both came with the same veggies: one giant cauliflower, one giant broccoli, and one giant piece of carrot - all three had to be cut to be eaten.

Overall, I would not recommend this place to any of my friends.
author: Austin C.

description:
We were shocked on NYE 2013 that this place was pretty empty, save for a handful of people @ 8:30p.   We scored parking on the street.   MSOB is a few doors down from that temple of hipness:  Mission Chinese/Lung Shan restaurant and even they were half empty at 10P.  We asked our waitress how long MSOB  had been open for business, surprisingly she said "almost 11 months"  admittedly, the location is on a part of mission street that hasn't been gentrified (yet) between 18th -19th streets, but we were content to not have to share our evening with the hoards. 

Food here is superb and reasonably priced.  For 2 of us, dinner with drinks was $125 before tip.   There were about 8 choices for oysters this night and the specials were Scottish Salmon, Trout and the lobster tail with potatoes gratin (yum!)  and to think I had booked us in at Fifth Floor and decided to cancel last minute after balking at  the $195 pp tasting menu with wine!  

Mission Street Oyster bar, we'll be back!
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: Absolutely love this place. Fantastic oysters at a great price. Friendly staff, fast service. Pretty much everything you could ask for at an oyster bar. Also really good draft beer too. Come here during happy hour for the $1.50 oysters and the amazingly addictive garlic bread. Only negative here is that this place is often empty. Not sure why, maybe the yuppies of the inner mission are afraid to walk into the slightly more "sketchy" part of town.
author: Tyler M.

description:
Ok, the chippino just happened to me!!

At first glance, you would just skip over this place, but do yourself a favor and stop in!

Service, stellar! Food amazing! I shared a Caesar salad with friends (typical salad) and had the chippino... What in the world so amazing! If you can finish in one serving, hats off to you.. I recommend sharing or taking some home for the next day.

5 stars, all the way!
author: Esprit S.

description:
We love Anchor Oyster Bar in the Castro and wanted to try this spot.  As I understand it's some of the same chefs from AOB but in a much more low-key and under the radar spot in the Mission.  

We went right for oysters and cioppino.  The cioppino was outstanding as expected and overall we had a great meal.  Great option if you're looking for delicious seafood without the wait of other places.  That said, needs to work it's decor and atmosphere to become a destination that I'm craving to go back to.
author: Rich L.

description: I was looking for a place to eat some raw oysters before we left San Francisco and found Mission Street Oyster Bar in my search. We got there about an hour before closing, and we were the only patrons in the place. That didn't take away from the service at all. The employees were friendly and welcoming even though the place was empty. I ordered a dozen raw oysters, and my fiancee and I split an appetizer. The food was good but fairly ordinary. Definitely not the best oysters I've had, but it was still an enjoyable time.
author: Charles H.

description:
I order the Alfredo Pasta and it was unseasoned, too oily, & really heavy. The Crab Cakes were again too heavy/oily and I couldn't distinctively taste the crab itself. The Cod Plate didn't have anything special about it and neither did its sides.

Overall, I thought the food was not very good and over priced. But the restaurant did have a really nice, open environment and friendly service.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: I really like this place!  My girlfriend and I are a mixed couple, in that she LOVES oysters and seafood and I'm not that big a fan.  But if you've got fish and chips on the menu and good beer on tap, I'm on board - and this place has both!  It's actually some of the best fish & chips I've ever had, and my sweetie has loved everything she's tried so far.  The staff are friendly and know their stuff (they could speak to the flavor of the different oysters/fish or tell us where it came from off the top of their heads, and have made some great recommendations).
author: Trilo B.

description:
So now the Mission has two good places to get Oysters now.  It's off the beaten path in a way since it's in the Mission which is not the typical place to go looking for an Oyster bar in San Francisco. I will admit I didn't have high expectations simply because of the reputation of some of the other oyster bars around town.  I can honestly say that I was truly pleasantly surprised.  It was completely empty when I went in so service was naturally good. She server at the bar was pleasant and knowledgeable in her description of the different oysters they have on hand.  Her one mistake was one I didn't catch till I was on my way out which was she charged me 12 dollars for a wine that was clearly advertised as 8 dollars on their menu board. Not a huge issue and it was something I should have caught earlier. I'm just chalking it up to a simple mistake.  She really pushed the garlic bread as being the best around and it was certainly good but a pretty big title to throw around for some bread, butter, and garlic. But I guess if all your regulars love it I can't really argue. For me personally it was a bit over the top and didn't really pair well with the oysters. 

All in all it's a great spot and I look forward to going back again.  Oh the bus person working there was a really nice guy too.
author: Joco F.

description:
$1 oyster happy hour even on the weekends? Score.
Many kinds of oysters to choose from during happy hour? Double score.
Beer specials to pair with oysters? Triple score.

Now...where is everyone? This place is so empty. While I'd like to keep it a secret, so that we can stuff ourselves silly with oysters - I really want to make sure it stays open and busy.

So grab all your friends and get to happy hour ASAP.
author: Marit S.

description:
We visited on a Sunday night, and the place was bursting at the seams. Two large parties had the front of the dining room filled. Upon arriving, we were greeted by one of the servers - he was very cordial and asked us to have a seat at the bar while they prepped our table. From what we observed, there were only 2 guys working the front of the house and nobody stationed behind an awkwardly large bar. I'm far from a restaurant expert, but the place seemed under-staffed. The design of the room seems very confused, with an enormous granite-topped bar, deep colors in the dining room, two awkward mounted Marlin on the walls and then... an Open kitchen that didn't really add any visual interest. At least it appeared very clean! That's a positive - right? :-) When our Uber driver dropped us off, we thought we were being punked - the surrounding area is a little "rough around the edges" in a visual way. Being from Philly, I have a buffer for that type of thing.

On to the real reason for our visit - The Food.
We based our visit purely on the Yelp reviews and our desire for fresh seafood. We were not disappointed!!! We started with a variety of Raw Oysters, our server was extremely knowledgable and helped us assemble a hit list of their offerings. We did a Briney vs. Creamy selection - based on his coaching - Excellent and VERY well priced!!! We split the house speciality - Cippino. After finishing the oysters, we watched a dozen orders of Cippino come through the dining room - our mouths with watering!!!!!

The Cippino - Comes with the BEST GARLIC BREAD you will EVER eat!!! We were advised by our server to give a 5 minute warning if we wanted more... Do yourself a favor and ORDER another round!!! You'll Want it and NEED IT to sop up the heavenly juice from the Cippino. Our bowl was FILLED with: mussels, shrimp, clams, crab meat, chunks of fish and a broth that was LOADED with flavor. Mesmerizing.

Drinks - we kept it simple: She had the Torontes (was a rather small pour for the $8.00 price point) and I had the Lagunitas IPA.

We walked away VERY satisfied with our visit. *I would rate the place higher if the room "felt" better. My thoughts on the appearance will NOT prevent me from visiting again!!! 
We loved it!
author: Bill M.

description: A new spot to get fresh oysters on a half shell. Plenty of seating and very friendly staff!
author: Carlos G.

description:
Great service / Great food / Modestly priced

The restaurant recently opened and is an absolutely great place to grab dinner and drinks. The quality of the seafood is best in class in San Francisco and the service is absolutely great. There is no fishy aftertaste with their seafood and the oysters are amazing! I highly recommend this place!
author: Heisenberg W.

description: This review is only for the oysters during happy hour. $1/ea?  Yes please! I appreciated the a choice of 4 different kinds of oysters during happy hour. It wasn't the most excellent shucking job but for that price, I won't complain!
author: Colene C.

description: When we walked up we couldn't tell if they were even open, they were and it was pretty empty.  I started to think we made a big mistake.  I was wrong, it was fabulous.  Service was fantastic, good selection of oysters and the cioppino was better than mine (that's hard to admit).  I wasn't a big fan of the garlic bread, I enjoyed the bread without all the butter and cheese but my husband loved it.  I would totally recommend it.
author: Meredith J.

description:
I pass by Mission Street Oyster everyday.  I finally went in with my partner.  Amazing FRESH OYSTERS and STEAMED CLAMS.  And the garlic bread AMAZING.   

The staff were very pleasant.  Its not trendy.  Its the real Mish.
author: Mark S.

description: This place is a gem serving very fresh seafood. Went in for lunch today for an Oyster craving. Actually wanted Swans but forgot they are on summer break for a week. But very glad I got to try this place. Sat at the counter as the place was not very busy and wanted the feel of Swans. This place is run by a sweet Hispanic couple, husband runs the kitchen the wife waits tables. Had a dozen oysters: Kumamoto, Chesapeake Bay and another from Washington state. Also tried the Seafood Gazpacho which I highly recommend. The husband would stop by as he was dropping off food to other tables and show us each dish. Everything looked delish!  He gave us a free order of garlic bread which went well with the Gazpacho. Def coming back for happy hour $1 oysters and the soup looks great on a foggy day!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I'm on a kind of low carb, paleo type of diet right now and I really just didn't think I could eat any more beef or chicken tonight. I had almost lost hope trying to come up with an idea for dinner tonight and then it came to me: cioppino.

Now let me start out by saying that I actually don't love shellfish and I probably only eat it once a year. I mean, it is typically prepared in such a way to hide the flavor as much as possible, often just poor quality (which is why you want to hide its flavor) and generally a pain in the butt to eat, 

The cioppino at Mission Street Oyster Bar though is none of those things. The sweet flavor of the crab and mussels shone through the slightly spicy, slightly sweet tomato broth. The quality was clearly high. The crab was de-shelled. Ok the mussels were still a pain to eat as were the shrimp, but people seem to like having mussel shells and shrimp tails in their soup so what can you do?

I was a little worried about the portion size. The photos here made it look rather small which considering the price worried me a bit, but it was more food than I could eat one once. 

I should note that I ordered this all via Postmates. There is always a risk ordering something like cioppino to go because of how it gets packaged. They packed it in a box (lined with some tin foil). It *almost* got to me in tact. I lost a wee bit of broth in the bag. Luckily, the box waited until I had started pouring it into a bowl to fully disintegrate. I'd be hesitant to order it again to go, but considering how good it was, I might risk it again.
author: Jordan M.

description:
$1 Happy Hour oysters are awesome.  The quality is what one should expect.  Service was friendly.

But an empty restaurant kind of kills the experience, and it was really slow when I last came.  The remedy?  Add more drink specials, please!!  Alcohol is always a party.
author: Diane N.

description:
Please don't anyone find out about this place - because this is now my favorite restaurant in SF.  

The oyster selection is outstanding.  The server described the taste and size on each of their selection - and they were pretty much right now.  

When it was crab season, the chef roasted crab in butter, garlic and misc. spices.  OMG, it was amazing.  We all over ate because we were enjoying it so much.  I'm now counting down to crab season so I can go back for that dish again.

My next mission at the Mission Street Oyster Bar - go there for happy hour and enjoy $1 oysters.
author: Stacey D.

description:
This place is a find!  I don't understand why more people don't go to this restaurant. The food is great, and the prices are totally reasonable.  The service was good too.  

I picked this place because I could get a reservation for a large group. I was not disappointed.  The way the tables are arranged makes the space look a bit empty, so that could be improved.
author: Catherine T.

description: Great  service . We got crab sandwich with clam chowder and an order of oysters. Everything tasted very fresh .
author: Milenka C.

description:
My new happy hour spot! 

$1 oysters until 6pm, 4 blocks from work. $2.50 draft beers as well. Love it!
author: Derrick V.

description:
Amazing place! Don't make the mistake of not trying the Cioppino. It was delicious. Oysters were GREAT too. Wasn't packed as I expected it to be. Great and fast service. I went one weekend and had to bring another friend the NEXT weekend. Thinking of bringing a new friend here each week as an excuse to eat here again!

Oh and I can't forget about the garlic bread. You will definitely want to order an extra round with the Cioppino. Yum in my tum.
author: Malika A.

description:
So glad Yelp! "liked" my tip and reminded me to write a review.

I came here on Saturday.  We came in before their daily happy hour at 3pm and ordered clam chowder.  The portions here are very small considering the prices.  The clam chowder tasted very water'ed down.  As we waited for the oyster happy hour to start, a few other parties came in.  (BTW, we were sitting at the bar).  When 3pm hit, I ordered 6 - 2 of each type they have on special.  They give you 3 choices for happy hour, which is great.  I didn't get my oysters for 20 minutes - they told me that they bring the orders out by their ticket order, but one of the parties that came in after me got their happy hour oysters AND finished them, before I even got mine.  And, let me remind you, we were there before 3pm.  

Anyway, I asked where my order was at 3:20pm, and shortly after, the waitress brings it out.  She leaves without explaining which oysters were which... another example of poor service.

I must say, the oysters were great - fresh and ocean-y just the way oysters shoudl be.  I loved the local ones they had on special that day (see, the names aren't sticking anymore because the waitress didn't tell me!)  

Anyway, I recommend coming in for the HH oysters ONLY and expect to wait awhile... a long while.  On the upside (or is it?), they're REALLY fast about giving you your check when you ask/ sliding your card and giving you your receipt.  It's only the food you have to wait for.
author: Joyce C.

description:
2.5 Stars.

LUCKILY they only allow you to order a Maximum of one dozens oysters each because my gf and i usually order 2 dozens EACH.

Out of the 24 oysters we had, at least 5 were spoiled ack. Like that really nasty taste in your mouth after you had bad snails -- exxaaaactly. nasty.

Seafood Salad was $22.99 and definitely not impressed at all. I would be JUMPING for joy if each mouth full was juicy crab, but it just wasn't.

At least I checked this place off my list, as I've been wanting to go for a while.

Save yourself a Trip/Tip/Money..

One Beer
24 Oysters
1 Seafood Salad
plus Tip: $68 OUCH!

(Female) Waitress was super friendly and nice. 2.5 All belongs to her.

best of luck, sorry!
author: Braden B.

description:
Marina prices in the Mission. The $1 oysters and 2.50 happy hour (3pm-6pm) are the steals here while the rest of the menu is decent but not special.

Came in at 5pm to an already almost full restaurant and got 2 dozen oysters and a bowl of steamed shellfish. It looked like we got three different kinds of oysters but I have no idea as our server never told us what they were or where they were from. They were all well shucked and fresh. 

The mussels were the best thing in the steamed shellfish. The shrimp were overcooked and the clams were very small. 

Most the larger dishes were over $15 with fish and chips being 15 dollars.

The space looks like it's still being worked on with no lighting other than over the bar and a sparse selection of tables.

The service was friendly, timely if a bit light on information about the menu.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Cheap, quick, delicious - 8 oysters on board. Sit at the bar, easily walk in even on Friday nights.
author: Ryan K.

description: Goodness Gracias, it was Fabulous. Freddy was a fabulous server and gave great recommendations. We loved the Cioppino, clam chowder, and oysters. Very happy:)
author: Courtnee R.

description:
Came here with the gf during happy hour, and like the stars suggest, it was "A-OK".

The location is clutch because I live about 5 blocks away.  The big draw was $1 oysters, natch.  We ordered them, and began to consume. 

Oysters - A.  I'm no connoisseur, but they had a variety of oysters that qualified for the $1 special, and others that didn't.

Beer - Really good selection on tap that also have happy hour specials

Sides - Here's where it sucked.  Ordered the seasoned potatoes, and they came out lukewarm on the outside and cold in the middle.  Pretty terrible.  We also had a side of steamed veggies which look like they came from an individual steam bag one buys at the supermarket.  

Stick to Oysters and Beer, don't make our mistake.
author: Peter C.

description:
This place is great for their oyster happy hour. They offer a couple choices of oysters for $1.50 each during their happy hour. The oysters were fresh and delicious! We also tried their steamed mussels, which were also very good. They were well cooked and had great seasoning.

The waiter was attentive, but not super attentive. They were quick to take away our empty plates, but felt like we had to wave them down to order more food.

Overall pretty good food and decent service. Would definitely come back again.
author: Jing W.

description:
I like oysters.  I like beer.  For happy hour at $1 a pop oysters (3 choices people, 3!) and $2.50 beers I'm a happy camper.  

Haven't eaten the real food here, but the garlic bread was good...does that count?  Probably not.  Did I mention $1 oyster happy hour?
author: A A.

description:
This has quickly become a favorite place to grab oysters for Saturday lunch. Sure, we may miss out on happy hour prices, but we also miss out on the crowds.
Service has been great the 3 times we've gone, and the selection of oyster -- usually 5 or 6 -- has been really good. The oysters are consistently good, fresh and tasty. The seafood gazpacho is great; TONS of shrimp, prawns, and crab jammed into a bowl of gazpacho. We also got a seafood combo salad that also had tons of seafood and really fresh greens.
Really relaxed atmosphere. NO crowds lunchtime. Incredibly fresh seafood.
author: Margie L.

description:
Stopped by around 3pm yesterday, coincidentally when happy hour starts.  I didn't know what to expect since there weren't many yelp reviews yet (later found out they've only been around for 7 months) and the location wasn't in the best part of town.  

They def exceeded my expectations.  Freddie (owner) was super friendly and honest when I asked him about his recipe.  I loved the $1 Cheseapeake oysters he recommended and enjoyed the mimosa.  Steamed mussels & bread were absolutely delicious!
author: Judie C.

description:
Have already been to this place twice since it opened, which is just a week or two. That's because of their happy hour, which is $1/oyster and $2.50 draft beers until 6 pm. 

In fairness, I haven't tried anything on the menu other than oysters, but who needs to when they've got that happy hour deal! I probably ate a dozen and a half yesterday and they were fantastic. Miyagi oysters were the best, but they were all good. Servers were very friendly and brought us free garlic bread, presumably on account of their recent opening. Fine with me. 

Good bar selection, though only beer and wine, which usually would be fine for a restaurant, but the oysters sort of demanded a martini. Ambiance and the rest will come once they get more settled. 

Definitely check this place out, ideally before 6 for the great deal.
author: David P.

description:
Hands down the freshest, best scallops I have ever had. Puts the scallops at Epic to shame. 

Wow. We just had one of those "run home to write a Yelp review" experiences. We were lucky enough to be made privy to the "soft opening" here and I am so, so grateful! This restaurant was just opened by the former chef (of 18 years) of Anchor Oyster Bar in the Castro. This man knows his seafood.  Keep in mind this restaurant is just opening, so all of the decor is not complete, BUT THE SEAFOOD IS SO FRESH! 

Here is what we ate. I recommend ALL of it: 
- Oysters (duh)
 - Steamed clams and mussels
- Garlic Bread... wow. 
- Shrimp Cesar Salad (with croutons so freshly made they were still warm)
- Trout (I NEVER eat trout. I scarfed this down!) 
- Scallops.... to kill for. 

Everything here is so fresh that there was no "fishy" smell or taste to anything we ate. Nice beer selection, too. I love the Deschutes Chainbreaker.
author: Robynne W.

description:
Loved the food and service! We actually liked the ambience too- we were expecting something terrible after reading some of the reviews, but the place is actually pretty cute with it's own personal Mission-vibe. No weird smells as we walked in either. We ordered a combination of oysters on the half-shell, the Ahi-tuna and the Alaskan cod (two of their specials) and everything tasted great. I'd definitely recommend this place.. unless you're overly finicky and would rather wait in line for hours at Anchor.

Parking is a nuisance but that's just the Mission.
author: Ruheene J.

description: Fantastic crab and excellent clam chowder!! The server was very nice and helped me choose the perfect lunch from their specials board...everything looked amazing on the menu so I needed a suggestion!! He made sure to tell me that the crab was fresh lump crabmeat, not a breaded patty...that made all the difference! I jumped on it and I was not disappointed! Two thumbs up, I can't wait to bring my New Orleans native parents to eat here when they come to visit!!
author: Jandi F.

description: Delicious!!  Cioppino  enough for two and was filled to the brim with delicious, fresh  shellfish. Rock point oysters big and juicy. Customer service is awesome. Will be coming back.
author: Margs B.

description: Had the mission St. Special appetizer and the steamed muscle dish, super delicious! Will try the oysters next time. Parking is so difficult in the mission as expected, but worth the effort.
author: Shawn L.

description: Best po' boy sandwich I've ever had. Perfectly spiced, good portion size, and well cooked oysters. Prices were good; honestly, after eating that sandwich I'd pay more. Good chowder, and the Chainbreaker IPA they have on tap is a nice, refreshing take on the genre.
author: Andy S.

description: Mediocre at best oysters. The house white is the first wine I've tasted and realized I was drinking a cheap wine
author: Robert S.

description:
This place is decent. Their oysters are fresh and a really good deal. We didn't have issues finding a seat. 

Perhaps because it's new, but they seemed a bit rough around the corner. Their servers were really nice, but duplicated efforts on a number of times. Their seating was spread out in a way that didn't maximize their floor space.

I honestly can't remember what i had besides oysters, so it can't be anything special or dissapointing.
author: Winny F.

description:
Paper-napkin bomb ass seafood spot.
We had a party of 6 and prolly tried er'thang on the menu- all delish. Minus one star for uneven service and the fact that the two rare ahi tunas we ordered came out cooked completely differently- that's how I knew for sure my rare was anything but. Also, don't go for the service- I went in with low expectations here and so wasn't too let down. But it was just so uneven that I have to comment on it anyway. Other than that, a legit spot to go and get your finger sucking on.
author: Isa L.

description: Yummy seafood.  The Mission Fried Special has shrimp, oysters, and calamari.  The oysters were lightly breaded and delicious.  I really liked them.  I would go back just for the oysters!!
author: C L.

description:
Happy hour even on weekends!

The staff is very friendly and the establishment was spotlessly clean. I don't have much to say about the food because we only got oysters and clam chowder. I highly suggest the Chesapeake bay oysters from Maryland. I was shocked at how much sweeter they are than the ones from Japan.

Clam chowder was nice on a freezing cold day.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
A decent meal, but I expect you can get better quality at the same price elsewhere nearby.  Had the fried oysters, which were a bit overdone, and crabcakes, which were good but nothing special.  The decor leaves a lot to be desired, and the space seems big and empty.

 A solid option on Mission St, but not a place I would go out of my way for.
author: Ross L.

description:
This review is for the Oyster Happy Hour that goes from 3p to 6p and offers oysters for $1 each.

There isn't really an "oyster bar" in the sense that I could watch my oysters being shucked while enjoying a nice, cold glass of beer, which is misleading because the name of the place implies that there is an oyster bar inside. 

The menu also focuses mostly on seafood dishes, like calamari or shrimp pasta, and oysters on the half shell aren't even listed on the menu. My main gripe about Mission Street Oyster Bar is that they only had three varieties of oysters that day. I don't know how they can call themselves an "oyster bar" by only offering three varieties. The Bay area is ripe with oyster farms, so I know it's not for lack of abundance. 

Oysters are also served with cocktail sauce and freshly grated horseradish - which is puzzling to me because any oyster-lover will know that cocktail sauce completely covers the natural flavors of the oyster and any oyster that needs such a sauce is not worth eating. They can have cocktail sauce upon request, but a mignonette might be a better to serve it with. 

That said, the oysters were fresh though I did get a couple of shells in my oysters and $1 an oyster for HH appears to be a good deal.
author: Stina M.

description:
The interior looks underwhelming, but I honestly don't gauge a place by the interior. The staff was very nice and knowledgeable, recommending oysters to us easily based on what we preferred.

The food was amazing - oysters were fresh and a good selection, and all the fish dishes were delicious and you can tell they were fresh.

Everything was reasonably priced, too, making it even more attractive.
author: Ellen S.

description: Truly disappointed. Brought in a group of 10. We ordered a lot of food and alcohol. No reason for the server to overcharge for the alcohol. He was getting his mandatory 20% tip too. Yet he told us $25 a bottle for soju and ended up charging us $54 a bottle. Really??? Bait and switch or just misquoted on purpose, either way, it's wrong to be so shady. Food was fine, could be better but paying more than double what was quoted for alcohol is wrong. We will never come back.
author: JungHyun H.

description:
This place has only been open a few days and it's already clear that the chef knows what he's doing. Perfectly executed seafood that is fresh fresh fresh, with friendly service to boot!

Highlights included a great selection of oysters, Cioppino (wanted to drink the broth it was so good), buttery garlic cheese bread (I lost count of how many pieces I ate), absolutely KILLER scallops, and meaty crab cakes lightly fried to perfection. They also have a sizable offering of beer and wine.

Ambiance is still a work-in-progress -- they didn't have any art on the walls yet. It's a nice big space though with a large bar area and I'm looking forward to seeing what happens once they complete the decor and more people start showing up.

A very promising addition to the neighborhood! Can't wait to go back and try the caesar salad, chowder and pasta.
author: jess l.

description: We just walked in here on a whim and it was an excellent choice. They have a good variety of oysters and their seafood and fish is awesome.
author: Chris M.

description: One word Delish!!!!
author: Emi J.

description: Stopped in tonight based off Yelp reviews and y'all are so on point for this spot!! Had 5 the $2 oysters as a starter and the Stuffed Sole dinner special. So pleased with this place. I'll be back for sure. Damn near every bite got the "Umm Humm, Damn!!" seal of approval.
author: Jayson S.

description:
Food is delicious, portions are generous and service is friendly. The only thing lacking is the decor (as other reviewers have mentioned) but the food more than makes up for it. The cooked whole Dungeoness Crab was awesome, and the cioppino was to die for.

I shouldn't post about this place because it seems like a hidden gem that I ought to keep to myself. Smack in the middle of the hippest part of Mission Street, the restaurant was half-full, no wait, at 7:30 on a Saturday night. 

Ultimately, my desire to keep this secret to myself is outweighed by the desire to see great food succeed.
author: Chris S.

description:
I met Chef Fredy and learned that he has over 18 years of experience working with seafood, and you can taste it in every bite.

The Cioppino (Italian Seafood Soup) was one of the best tasting seafood soups I've ever had.  The savory homemade broth complemented the FRESH mountain of clams, crab legs and prawns.  It was a filling dish enough for two!

We also tried the Gazpacho, a dish which I'm not usually a fan of (soup should be served hot!), but this had me rethinking my tastes.  It had so much good crab, oysters, clams, and shrimp in it that we were completely stuffed by the end of it.

On top of that, our servers were very friendly and Chef Fredy is very passionate about his craft.  Definitely plan to come back!  They are close to a full five stars if our second and third experiences are just as delicious.  #NOM #SEAFOODPORN
author: Nelson N.

description: An average seafood whole-in-the-wall. I tried there clam chowder which was not bad. Oysters had a good variety and were not bad. Nothing exciting, I would not go out of my way for them, may be if I was around and graving for oysters. Services was good though, ppl were friendly.
author: Zici L.

description:
Although this doesn't seem to be the place to go for Oysters, it really is. Don't let the surrounding neighborhood deter you- Happy Hour here is amazing with $1 Oysters and $2.50 Draft Beers. (Happy Hour goes until 6PM) They also give you this garlic cheese bread which was borderline orgasmic. We ordered a dozen oysters and they gave us an assorted plate from the little Kumomotos to really big ones.
Restaurant and bathroom were both very clean. Staff was very nice, attentive and friendly. 
I really didn't want to Yelp about this place because I don't want it to get super packed and ruined as a nice little hidden gem but I'm not selfish and felt it was only right to share.
author: Kajal G.

description:
What a great find! Mission Street Oyster Bar is a place that, so far, has gone somewhat unnoticed. You'll feel like you've discovered something no one else knows about.

This new restaurant will soon be a neighborhood staple for the Mission. We went for a quiet weeknight dinner and left very satisfied. I could not have been happier with the experience.

From the initial welcome to our goodbyes, the service was friendly and considerate. The wait staff wanted to make sure our experience was well-balanced and that we were satisfied. Could not be happier with the service.

The seafood was wonderful. We started with oysters, moved on to chowder, and finished with an entree (that night's special: crab-stuffed sole). The special really felt special and fresh. You can't go wrong with their oysters and chowder. Great portions and great taste.
author: Mark R.

description:
I keep going back to this simple, non-pretentious and delicious place!  Love it.  Great oysters & garlic bread.  Amazing and fresh shrimp cocktail and crab cocktail (like, an entire glass cup of amazing claw-meat), and the best spicy shrimp marinara pasta I've had in years.  Also, the garlic crab is delish.

It's awesome that the place isn't crowded, but they do need to work on service issues.  Pretty good wine and beer selection at decent prices.

Love this place!
author: Lita F.

description:
This is a great place to get your seafood fix!! Great, fresh seafood in the middle of a sketch neighborhood.  Vibe is pretty casual, I would recommend against dressing up unless you like attention from the neighborhood creepers and weirdos.

Here's what I recommend
-Three different types of Happy Hour Oysters
-Beer to go with your HH oysters
-Gazpacho

Seared Shrimp - this was all right.  I would probably try something different next time.
Garlic Bread - didn't like the butter or spread that was used

I really liked that everything on the menu is no-nonsense seafood.  Will be returning to try out other items!
author: Erica D.

description:
My friend recently stumbled upon this place after going to Hog & Rocks around 4 only to find it closed. So I met her there, sitting at the bar, which was not an oyster bar at all. Meaning, there was no one there shucking away. But I guess the term is used pretty loosely. Anyway...

My initial impressions are this: they still don't seem to quite have their act together. There was only one person handling both the bar and the eight or so tables. Occasionally a bus person or expediter would appear, but the woman behind the counter was pretty much on her own. So service was a bit slooooow. Plates sat in front of us a long time, even when it wasn't that busy. Kind of a pet peeve of mine.

My friend enjoyed the wine selection while I was happy to see Trumer Pils on tap. It was happy hour so the beer was $2.50 and three kinds of oysters were only a dollar (but not "premium" ones such as Kumamoto). 

The decor was pleasant and the place is pretty spacious and super clean, but the music was weird and confusing. It was not exactly tailored to the clientele. I swear I heard Pat Metheny.

Still, it was worth the trip. I will check it out again after it's been open a few more months.
author: Jess G.

description: Oysters were good. My favorite were the Chesapeakes. Our waiter was a bit pushy, but we did have a large group, so I guess I can understand why she wanted things in order, from her perspective. Chioppino is legit, clam chowder is legit. I would come back and recommend...especially since its right in the heart of the mission.
author: Tom L.

description: The clam chowder is amazing! Oysters were really good too! We had a really good experience here. The service was really good too. We will return the next time we come up to sf again.
author: Tricia E.

description: I think I'd give it 3.5 stars.  Happy hour deal for oysters was good but probably wouldn't go out of my way to come again, mostly bc service was not too friendly imo.  Just okay but am grateful to my bro who bought me oysters.  :)
author: Chrstina S.

description: I saw the reviews that said "don't let the neighborhood scare you off".  Well I'm not sure the neighborhood was that bad but what a great place.  We had the mission special with a number of different oysters, clams and prawns.  Fabulous. Very friendly staff. Only comment is its only beer/wine.  So if you want mixed drinks/booze you'll have to pick someplace else.
author: Jeremy D.

description: This place is really good. .. Had a nice day at delores found this place on the way home ... seafood pasta is hella good!
author: Tee D.

description: Food was good. I had the seafood combination salad. The food tasted fresh, which is obviously key w seafood. However, the chowder was pretty sub-par. And, I know this is a personal preference, but, they were playing dance/club music...on a Wednesday night...with 3 customers in the joint. Totally killed any ambiance and vibe. Service was a little slow but I'm from NYC so everything is slow to me. And since the price tag is on the high side, you're essentially paying for ambiance and service...both of which were sub-meh.
